scenes.location: Rossillon. A room in the Countess's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: In delivering my son from me, I bury a second husband.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: And I in going, madam, weep o'er my father's death anew; but I must attend his majesty's command, to whom I am now in ward, evermore in subjection.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: You shall find of the king a husband, madam; you, sir, a father. He that so generally is at all times good, must of necessity hold his virtue to you, whose worthiness would stir it up where it wanted, rather than lack it where there is such abundance.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: What hope is there of his majesty's amendment?

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: He hath abandon'd his physicians, madam; under whose practices he hath persecuted time with hope, and finds no other advantage in the process but only the losing of hope by time.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: This young gentlewoman had a father-O that "had!", how sad a passage 'tis!-whose skill was almost as great as his honesty; had it stretch'd so far, would have made nature immortal, and death should have play for lack of work. Would for the king's sake he were living! I think it would be the death of the king's disease.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: How called you the man you speak of, madam?

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: He was famous, sir, in his profession, and it was his great right to be so: Gerard de Narbon.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: He was excellent indeed, madam; the king very lately spoke of him admiringly, and mourningly; he was skilful enough to have liv'd still, if knowledge could be set up against mortality.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: What is it, my good lord, the king languishes of?

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: A fistula, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I heard not of it before.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I would it were not notorious. Was this gentlewoman the daughter of Gerard de Narbon?

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: His sole child, my lord, and bequeathed to my overlooking. I have those hopes of her good that her education promises her dispositions she inherits, which makes fair gifts fairer; for where an unclean mind carries virtuous qualities, there commendations go with pity, they are virtues and traitors too. In her they are the better for their simpleness; she derives her honesty, and achieves her goodness.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Your commendations, madam, get from her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: 'Tis the best brine a maiden can season her praise in. The remembrance of her father never approaches her heart but the tyranny of her sorrows takes all livelihood from her cheek. No more of this, Helena; go to, no more, lest it be rather thought you affect a sorrow than to have.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I do affect a sorrow indeed, but I have it too.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead; excessive grief the enemy to the living.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: If the living be enemy to the grief, the excess makes it soon mortal.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Madam, I desire your holy wishes.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: How understand we that?

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Be thou blest, Bertram, and succeed thy father In manners, as in shape! Thy blood and virtue Contend for empire in thee, and thy goodness Share with thy birthright! Love all, trust a few, Do wrong to none. Be able for thine enemy Rather in power than use; and keep thy friend Under thy own life's key. Be check'd for silence, But never tax'd for speech. What heaven more will, That thee may furnish and my prayers pluck down, Fall on thy head! Farewell. My lord, 'Tis an unseason'd courtier; good my lord, Advise him.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: He cannot want the best That shall attend his love.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Heaven bless him! Farewell, Bertram.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: The best wishes that can be forg'd in your thoughts be servants to you!  Be comfortable to my mother, your mistress, and make much of her.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Farewell, pretty lady, you must hold the credit of your father.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: O, were that all! I think not on my father, And these great tears grace his remembrance more Than those I shed for him. What was he like? I have forgot him; my imagination Carries no favour in't but Bertram's. I am undone: there is no living, none, If Bertram be away. 'Twere all one That I should love a bright particular star, And think to wed it, he is so above me. In his bright radiance and collateral light Must I be comforted, not in his sphere. Th'ambition in my love thus plagues itself: The hind that would be mated by the lion Must die for love. 'Twas pretty, though a plague, To see him every hour; to sit and draw His arched brows, his hawking eye, his curls, In our heart's table,-heart too capable Of every line and trick of his sweet favour. But now he's gone, and my idolatrous fancy Must sanctify his relics. Who comes here?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: One that goes with him: I love him for his sake, And yet I know him a notorious liar, Think him a great way fool, solely a coward; Yet these fix'd evils sit so fit in him That they take place when virtue's steely bones Looks bleak i' th' cold wind: withal, full oft we see Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Save you, fair queen!

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: And you, monarch!

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: And no.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Are you meditating on virginity?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Ay. You have some stain of soldier in you; let me ask you a question. Man is enemy to virginity; how may we barricado it against him?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Keep him out.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: But he assails; and our virginity, though valiant, in the defence, yet is weak. Unfold to us some warlike resistance.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: There is none. Man setting down before you will undermine you and blow you up.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Bless our poor virginity from underminers and blowers-up! Is there no military policy how virgins might blow up men?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Virginity being blown down, man will quicklier be blown up; marry, in blowing him down again, with the breach yourselves made, you lose your city. It is not politic in the commonwealth of nature to preserve virginity. Loss of virginity is rational increase, and there was never virgin got till virginity was first lost. That you were made of is metal to make virgins. Virginity, by being once lost, may be ten times found; by being ever kept, it is ever lost. 'Tis too cold a companion. Away with it!

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I will stand for't a little, though therefore I die a virgin.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: There's little can be said in't; 'tis against the rule of nature. To speak on the part of virginity is to accuse your mothers; which is most infallible disobedience. He that hangs himself is a virgin: virginity murders itself, and should be buried in highways out of all sanctified limit, as a desperate offendress against nature. Virginity breeds mites, much like a cheese; consumes itself to the very paring, and so proud, idle, made of self-love, which is the most inhibited sin in the canon. Keep it not; you cannot choose but lose by't. Out with't! Within the year it will make itself two, which is a goodly increase, and the principal itself not much the worse. Away with it!

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: How might one do, sir, to lose it to her own liking?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Let me see. Marry, ill, to like him that ne'er it likes. 'Tis a commodity will lose the gloss with lying; the longer kept, the less worth. Off with't while 'tis vendible; answer the time of request. Virginity, like an old courtier, wears her cap out of fashion, richly suited, but unsuitable, just like the brooch and the toothpick, which wear not now. Your date is better in your pie and your porridge than in your cheek. And your virginity, your old virginity, is like one of our French wither'd pears; it looks ill, it eats drily; marry, 'tis a wither'd pear; it was formerly better; marry, yet 'tis a wither'd pear. Will you anything with it?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Not my virginity yet. There shall your master have a thousand loves, A mother, and a mistress, and a friend, A phoenix, captain, and an enemy, A guide, a goddess, and a sovereign, A counsellor, a traitress, and a dear: His humble ambition, proud humility, His jarring concord, and his discord dulcet, His faith, his sweet disaster; with a world Of pretty, fond, adoptious christendoms That blinking Cupid gossips. Now shall he- I know not what he shall. God send him well! The court's a learning-place; and he is one.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: What one, i' faith?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: That I wish well. 'Tis pity-

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: What's pity?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: That wishing well had not a body in't Which might be felt, that we, the poorer born, Whose baser stars do shut us up in wishes, Might with effects of them follow our friends, And show what we alone must think, which never Returns us thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: Monsieur Parolles, my lord calls for you.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Little Helen, farewell. If I can remember thee, I will think of thee at court.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Monsieur Parolles, you were born under a charitable star.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Under Mars, I.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I especially think, under Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Why under Mars?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: The wars hath so kept you under, that you must needs be born under Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: When he was predominant.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: When he was retrograde, I think rather.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Why think you so?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: You go so much backward when you fight.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: That's for advantage.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: So is running away, when fear proposes the safety: but the composition that your valour and fear makes in you is a virtue of a good wing, and I like the wear well.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I am so full of business I cannot answer thee acutely. I will return perfect courtier; in the which my instruction shall serve to naturalize thee, so thou wilt be capable of a courtier's counsel, and understand what advice shall thrust upon thee; else thou diest in thine unthankfulness, and thine ignorance makes thee away. Farewell. When thou hast leisure, say thy prayers; when thou hast none, remember thy friends. Get thee a good husband, and use him as he uses thee. So, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie, Which we ascribe to heaven: the fated sky Gives us free scope; only doth backward pull Our slow designs when we ourselves are dull. What power is it which mounts my love so high, That makes me see, and cannot feed mine eye? The mightiest space in fortune nature brings To join like likes, and kiss like native things. Impossible be strange attempts to those That weigh their pains in sense, and do suppose What hath been cannot be. Who ever strove To show her merit that did miss her love? The king's disease,-my project may deceive me, But my intents are fix'd, and will not leave me.

scenes.location: Paris. A room in the King's palace.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: The Florentines and Senoys are by th' ears; Have fought with equal fortune, and continue A braving war.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: So 'tis reported, sir.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Nay, 'tis most credible, we here receive it, A certainty, vouch'd from our cousin Austria, With caution, that the Florentine will move us For speedy aid; wherein our dearest friend Prejudicates the business, and would seem To have us make denial.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: His love and wisdom, Approv'd so to your majesty, may plead For amplest credence.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: He hath arm'd our answer, And Florence is denied before he comes: Yet, for our gentlemen that mean to see The Tuscan service, freely have they leave To stand on either part.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: It well may serve A nursery to our gentry, who are sick For breathing and exploit.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What's he comes here?

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: It is the Count Rossillon, my good lord, Young Bertram.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Youth, thou bear'st thy father's face; Frank nature, rather curious than in haste, Hath well compos'd thee. Thy father's moral parts Mayst thou inherit too! Welcome to Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: My thanks and duty are your majesty's.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I would I had that corporal soundness now, As when thy father and myself in friendship First tried our soldiership. He did look far Into the service of the time, and was Discipled of the bravest. He lasted long, But on us both did haggish age steal on, And wore us out of act. It much repairs me To talk of your good father; in his youth He had the wit which I can well observe Today in our young lords; but they may jest Till their own scorn return to them unnoted Ere they can hide their levity in honour So like a courtier, contempt nor bitterness Were in his pride or sharpness; if they were, His equal had awak'd them, and his honour, Clock to itself, knew the true minute when Exception bid him speak, and at this time His tongue obey'd his hand. Who were below him He us'd as creatures of another place, And bow'd his eminent top to their low ranks, Making them proud of his humility, In their poor praise he humbled. Such a man Might be a copy to these younger times; Which, followed well, would demonstrate them now But goers backward.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: His good remembrance, sir, Lies richer in your thoughts than on his tomb; So in approof lives not his epitaph As in your royal speech.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Would I were with him! He would always say,- Methinks I hear him now; his plausive words He scatter'd not in ears, but grafted them To grow there and to bear,-"Let me not live," This his good melancholy oft began On the catastrophe and heel of pastime, When it was out,-"Let me not live" quoth he, "After my flame lacks oil, to be the snuff Of younger spirits, whose apprehensive senses All but new things disdain; whose judgments are Mere fathers of their garments; whose constancies Expire before their fashions." This he wish'd. I, after him, do after him wish too, Since I nor wax nor honey can bring home, I quickly were dissolved from my hive To give some labourers room.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: You're lov'd, sir; They that least lend it you shall lack you first.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I fill a place, I know't. How long is't, Count, Since the physician at your father's died? He was much fam'd.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Some six months since, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: If he were living, I would try him yet;- Lend me an arm;-the rest have worn me out With several applications; nature and sickness Debate it at their leisure. Welcome, Count; My son's no dearer.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Thank your majesty.

scenes.location: Rossillon. A Room in the Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: I will now hear. What say you of this gentlewoman?

dialogues.speaker: Steward
dialogues.line: Madam, the care I have had to even your content, I wish might be found in the calendar of my past endeavours; for then we wound our modesty, and make foul the clearness of our deservings, when of ourselves we publish them.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: What does this knave here? Get you gone, sirrah. The complaints I have heard of you I do not all believe; 'tis my slowness that I do not; for I know you lack not folly to commit them, and have ability enough to make such knaveries yours.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: 'Tis not unknown to you, madam, I am a poor fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Well, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: No, madam, 'tis not so well that I am poor, though many of the rich are damned; but if I may have your ladyship's good will to go to the world, Isbel the woman and I will do as we may.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Wilt thou needs be a beggar?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I do beg your good will in this case.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: In what case?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: In Isbel's case and mine own. Service is no heritage, and I think I shall never have the blessing of God till I have issue of my body; for they say barnes are blessings.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Tell me thy reason why thou wilt marry.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: My poor body, madam, requires it; I am driven on by the flesh, and he must needs go that the devil drives.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Is this all your worship's reason?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Faith, madam, I have other holy reasons, such as they are.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: May the world know them?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I have been, madam, a wicked creature, as you and all flesh and blood are; and indeed I do marry that I may repent.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Thy marriage, sooner than thy wickedness.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I am out of friends, madam, and I hope to have friends for my wife's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Such friends are thine enemies, knave.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Y'are shallow, madam, in great friends; for the knaves come to do that for me which I am a-weary of. He that ears my land spares my team, and gives me leave to in the crop: if I be his cuckold, he's my drudge. He that comforts my wife is the cherisher of my flesh and blood; he that cherishes my flesh and blood loves my flesh and blood; he that loves my flesh and blood is my friend; ergo, he that kisses my wife is my friend. If men could be contented to be what they are, there were no fear in marriage; for young Charbon the puritan and old Poysam the papist, howsome'er their hearts are sever'd in religion, their heads are both one; they may jowl horns together like any deer i' the herd.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Wilt thou ever be a foul-mouth'd and calumnious knave?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: A prophet I, madam; and I speak the truth the next way: _For I the ballad will repeat, Which men full true shall find; Your marriage comes by destiny, Your cuckoo sings by kind._

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Get you gone, sir; I'll talk with you more anon.

dialogues.speaker: Steward
dialogues.line: May it please you, madam, that he bid Helen come to you; of her I am to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Sirrah, tell my gentlewoman I would speak with her; Helen I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _   Was this fair face the cause, quoth she, Why the Grecians sacked Troy? Fond done, done fond, Was this King Priam's joy? With that she sighed as she stood, With that she sighed as she stood, And gave this sentence then: Among nine bad if one be good, Among nine bad if one be good, There's yet one good in ten._

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: What, one good in ten? You corrupt the song, sirrah.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: One good woman in ten, madam, which is a purifying o' the song. Would God would serve the world so all the year! We'd find no fault with the tithe-woman, if I were the parson. One in ten, quoth 'a! And we might have a good woman born but or every blazing star, or at an earthquake, 'twould mend the lottery well; a man may draw his heart out ere he pluck one.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: You'll be gone, sir knave, and do as I command you!

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: That man should be at woman's command, and yet no hurt done! Though honesty be no puritan, yet it will do no hurt; it will wear the surplice of humility over the black gown of a big heart. I am going, forsooth; the business is for Helen to come hither.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Well, now.

dialogues.speaker: Steward
dialogues.line: I know, madam, you love your gentlewoman entirely.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Faith I do. Her father bequeath'd her to me, and she herself, without other advantage, may lawfully make title to as much love as she finds; there is more owing her than is paid, and more shall be paid her than she'll demand.

dialogues.speaker: Steward
dialogues.line: Madam, I was very late more near her than I think she wish'd me; alone she was, and did communicate to herself her own words to her own ears; she thought, I dare vow for her, they touch'd not any stranger sense. Her matter was, she loved your son. Fortune, she said, was no goddess, that had put such difference betwixt their two estates; Love no god, that would not extend his might only where qualities were level; Diana no queen of virgins, that would suffer her poor knight surpris'd, without rescue in the first assault or ransom afterward. This she deliver'd in the most bitter touch of sorrow that e'er I heard virgin exclaim in, which I held my duty speedily to acquaint you withal; sithence, in the loss that may happen, it concerns you something to know it.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: You have discharg'd this honestly; keep it to yourself; many likelihoods inform'd me of this before, which hung so tottering in the balance that I could neither believe nor misdoubt. Pray you leave me; stall this in your bosom; and I thank you for your honest care. I will speak with you further anon. Even so it was with me when I was young; If ever we are nature's, these are ours; this thorn Doth to our rose of youth rightly belong; Our blood to us, this to our blood is born; It is the show and seal of nature's truth, Where love's strong passion is impress'd in youth. By our remembrances of days foregone, Such were our faults, or then we thought them none. Her eye is sick on't; I observe her now.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: What is your pleasure, madam?

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: You know, Helen, I am a mother to you.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Mine honourable mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Nay, a mother. Why not a mother? When I said a mother, Methought you saw a serpent. What's in mother, That you start at it? I say I am your mother, And put you in the catalogue of those That were enwombed mine. 'Tis often seen Adoption strives with nature, and choice breeds A native slip to us from foreign seeds. You ne'er oppress'd me with a mother's groan, Yet I express to you a mother's care. God's mercy, maiden! does it curd thy blood To say I am thy mother? What's the matter, That this distempered messenger of wet, The many-colour'd Iris, rounds thine eye? -Why, that you are my daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: That I am not.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: I say, I am your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Pardon, madam; The Count Rossillon cannot be my brother. I am from humble, he from honoured name; No note upon my parents, his all noble, My master, my dear lord he is; and I His servant live, and will his vassal die. He must not be my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Nor I your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: You are my mother, madam; would you were- So that my lord your son were not my brother,- Indeed my mother! or were you both our mothers, I care no more for than I do for heaven, So I were not his sister. Can't no other, But, I your daughter, he must be my brother?

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Yes, Helen, you might be my daughter-in-law. God shield you mean it not! daughter and mother So strive upon your pulse. What! pale again? My fear hath catch'd your fondness; now I see The mystery of your loneliness, and find Your salt tears' head. Now to all sense 'tis gross You love my son; invention is asham'd, Against the proclamation of thy passion To say thou dost not. Therefore tell me true; But tell me then, 'tis so; for, look, thy cheeks Confess it, t'one to th'other; and thine eyes See it so grossly shown in thy behaviours, That in their kind they speak it; only sin And hellish obstinacy tie thy tongue, That truth should be suspected. Speak, is't so? If it be so, you have wound a goodly clew; If it be not, forswear't: howe'er, I charge thee, As heaven shall work in me for thine avail, To tell me truly.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Good madam, pardon me.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Do you love my son?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Your pardon, noble mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Love you my son?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Do not you love him, madam?

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Go not about; my love hath in't a bond Whereof the world takes note. Come, come, disclose The state of your affection, for your passions Have to the full appeach'd.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Then I confess, Here on my knee, before high heaven and you, That before you, and next unto high heaven, I love your son. My friends were poor, but honest; so's my love. Be not offended; for it hurts not him That he is lov'd of me; I follow him not By any token of presumptuous suit, Nor would I have him till I do deserve him; Yet never know how that desert should be. I know I love in vain, strive against hope; Yet in this captious and inteemable sieve I still pour in the waters of my love And lack not to lose still. Thus, Indian-like, Religious in mine error, I adore The sun that looks upon his worshipper, But knows of him no more. My dearest madam, Let not your hate encounter with my love, For loving where you do; but if yourself, Whose aged honour cites a virtuous youth, Did ever, in so true a flame of liking, Wish chastely, and love dearly, that your Dian Was both herself and love; O then, give pity To her whose state is such that cannot choose But lend and give where she is sure to lose; That seeks not to find that her search implies, But riddle-like, lives sweetly where she dies!

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Had you not lately an intent,-speak truly,- To go to Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Madam, I had.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Wherefore? tell true.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I will tell truth; by grace itself I swear. You know my father left me some prescriptions Of rare and prov'd effects, such as his reading And manifest experience had collected For general sovereignty; and that he will'd me In heedfull'st reservation to bestow them, As notes whose faculties inclusive were More than they were in note. Amongst the rest There is a remedy, approv'd, set down, To cure the desperate languishings whereof The king is render'd lost.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: This was your motive For Paris, was it? Speak.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: My lord your son made me to think of this; Else Paris, and the medicine, and the king, Had from the conversation of my thoughts Haply been absent then.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: But think you, Helen, If you should tender your supposed aid, He would receive it? He and his physicians Are of a mind; he, that they cannot help him; They, that they cannot help. How shall they credit A poor unlearned virgin, when the schools, Embowell'd of their doctrine, have let off The danger to itself?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: There's something in't More than my father's skill, which was the great'st Of his profession, that his good receipt Shall for my legacy be sanctified By th' luckiest stars in heaven; and would your honour But give me leave to try success, I'd venture The well-lost life of mine on his grace's cure. By such a day, an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Dost thou believe't?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Ay, madam, knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Why, Helen, thou shalt have my leave and love, Means and attendants, and my loving greetings To those of mine in court. I'll stay at home, And pray God's blessing into thy attempt. Be gone tomorrow; and be sure of this, What I can help thee to, thou shalt not miss.

scenes.location: Paris. A room in the King's palace.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Farewell, young lords; these warlike principles Do not throw from you; and you, my lords, farewell; Share the advice betwixt you; if both gain all, The gift doth stretch itself as 'tis receiv'd, And is enough for both.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: 'Tis our hope, sir, After well-ent'red soldiers, to return And find your grace in health.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: No, no, it cannot be; and yet my heart Will not confess he owes the malady That doth my life besiege. Farewell, young lords. Whether I live or die, be you the sons Of worthy Frenchmen; let higher Italy,- Those bated that inherit but the fall Of the last monarchy-see that you come Not to woo honour, but to wed it, when The bravest questant shrinks: find what you seek, That fame may cry you loud. I say farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Health, at your bidding serve your majesty!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Those girls of Italy, take heed of them; They say our French lack language to deny If they demand; beware of being captives Before you serve.

dialogues.speaker: Both
dialogues.line: Our hearts receive your warnings.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Farewell.-Come hither to me.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: O my sweet lord, that you will stay behind us!

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: 'Tis not his fault; the spark.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: O, 'tis brave wars!

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Most admirable! I have seen those wars.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I am commanded here, and kept a coil with, "Too young", and "the next year" and "'tis too early".

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: An thy mind stand to't, boy, steal away bravely.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I shall stay here the forehorse to a smock, Creaking my shoes on the plain masonry, Till honour be bought up, and no sword worn But one to dance with. By heaven, I'll steal away.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: There's honour in the theft.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Commit it, count.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: I am your accessary; and so farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I grow to you, and our parting is a tortur'd body.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Farewell, captain.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Sweet Monsieur Parolles!

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Noble heroes, my sword and yours are kin. Good sparks and lustrous, a word, good metals. You shall find in the regiment of the Spinii one Captain Spurio, with his cicatrice, an emblem of war, here on his sinister cheek; it was this very sword entrench'd it. Say to him I live; and observe his reports for me.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: We shall, noble captain.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Mars dote on you for his novices! What will ye do?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Stay the king.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Use a more spacious ceremony to the noble lords; you have restrain'd yourself within the list of too cold an adieu. Be more expressive to them; for they wear themselves in the cap of the time; there do muster true gait; eat, speak, and move, under the influence of the most receiv'd star; and though the devil lead the measure, such are to be followed. After them, and take a more dilated farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: And I will do so.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Worthy fellows, and like to prove most sinewy sword-men.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Pardon, my lord , for me and for my tidings.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I'll fee thee to stand up.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Then here's a man stands that has brought his pardon. I would you had kneel'd, my lord, to ask me mercy, And that at my bidding you could so stand up.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I would I had; so I had broke thy pate, And ask'd thee mercy for't.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Good faith, across; But, my good lord, 'tis thus: will you be cur'd Of your infirmity?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: O, will you eat No grapes, my royal fox? Yes, but you will My noble grapes, and if my royal fox Could reach them. I have seen a medicine That's able to breathe life into a stone, Quicken a rock, and make you dance canary With sprightly fire and motion; whose simple touch Is powerful to araise King Pippen, nay, To give great Charlemain a pen in's hand And write to her a love-line.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What ‘her' is this?

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Why, doctor ‘she'! My lord, there's one arriv'd, If you will see her. Now, by my faith and honour, If seriously I may convey my thoughts In this my light deliverance, I have spoke With one that in her sex, her years, profession, Wisdom, and constancy, hath amaz'd me more Than I dare blame my weakness. Will you see her, For that is her demand, and know her business? That done, laugh well at me.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Now, good Lafew, Bring in the admiration; that we with thee May spend our wonder too, or take off thine By wond'ring how thou took'st it.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Nay, I'll fit you, And not be all day neither.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Thus he his special nothing ever prologues.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Nay, come your ways.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: This haste hath wings indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Nay, come your ways. This is his majesty, say your mind to him. A traitor you do look like, but such traitors His majesty seldom fears; I am Cressid's uncle, That dare leave two together. Fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Now, fair one, does your business follow us?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Ay, my good lord. Gerard de Narbon was my father, In what he did profess, well found.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I knew him.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: The rather will I spare my praises towards him. Knowing him is enough. On his bed of death Many receipts he gave me; chiefly one, Which, as the dearest issue of his practice, And of his old experience the only darling, He bade me store up as a triple eye, Safer than mine own two; more dear I have so, And hearing your high majesty is touch'd With that malignant cause, wherein the honour Of my dear father's gift stands chief in power, I come to tender it, and my appliance, With all bound humbleness.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: We thank you, maiden, But may not be so credulous of cure, When our most learned doctors leave us, and The congregated college have concluded That labouring art can never ransom nature From her inaidable estate. I say we must not So stain our judgment, or corrupt our hope, To prostitute our past-cure malady To empirics, or to dissever so Our great self and our credit, to esteem A senseless help, when help past sense we deem.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: My duty then shall pay me for my pains. I will no more enforce mine office on you, Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts A modest one to bear me back again.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I cannot give thee less, to be call'd grateful. Thou thought'st to help me; and such thanks I give As one near death to those that wish him live. But what at full I know, thou know'st no part; I knowing all my peril, thou no art.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: What I can do can do no hurt to try, Since you set up your rest 'gainst remedy. He that of greatest works is finisher Oft does them by the weakest minister. So holy writ in babes hath judgment shown, When judges have been babes. Great floods have flown From simple sources, and great seas have dried When miracles have by the great'st been denied. Oft expectation fails, and most oft there Where most it promises; and oft it hits Where hope is coldest, and despair most fits.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I must not hear thee. Fare thee well, kind maid. Thy pains, not us'd, must by thyself be paid; Proffers, not took, reap thanks for their reward.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Inspired merit so by breath is barr'd. It is not so with Him that all things knows As 'tis with us that square our guess by shows; But most it is presumption in us when The help of heaven we count the act of men. Dear sir, to my endeavours give consent; Of heaven, not me, make an experiment. I am not an impostor, that proclaim Myself against the level of mine aim, But know I think, and think I know most sure, My art is not past power nor you past cure.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Art thou so confident? Within what space Hop'st thou my cure?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: The greatest grace lending grace. Ere twice the horses of the sun shall bring Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring, Ere twice in murk and occidental damp Moist Hesperus hath quench'd her sleepy lamp; Or four and twenty times the pilot's glass Hath told the thievish minutes how they pass; What is infirm from your sound parts shall fly, Health shall live free, and sickness freely die.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Upon thy certainty and confidence What dar'st thou venture?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Tax of impudence, A strumpet's boldness, a divulged shame, Traduc'd by odious ballads; my maiden's name Sear'd otherwise; nay worse of worst extended With vilest torture, let my life be ended.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Methinks in thee some blessed spirit doth speak His powerful sound within an organ weak; And what impossibility would slay In common sense, sense saves another way. Thy life is dear, for all that life can rate Worth name of life in thee hath estimate: Youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, all That happiness and prime can happy call. Thou this to hazard needs must intimate Skill infinite, or monstrous desperate. Sweet practiser, thy physic I will try, That ministers thine own death if I die.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: If I break time, or flinch in property Of what I spoke, unpitied let me die, And well deserv'd. Not helping, death's my fee; But if I help, what do you promise me?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Make thy demand.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: But will you make it even?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Ay, by my sceptre and my hopes of heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Then shalt thou give me, with thy kingly hand What husband in thy power I will command: Exempted be from me the arrogance To choose from forth the royal blood of France, My low and humble name to propagate With any branch or image of thy state; But such a one, thy vassal, whom I know Is free for me to ask, thee to bestow.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Here is my hand; the premises observ'd, Thy will by my performance shall be serv'd; So make the choice of thy own time, for I, Thy resolv'd patient, on thee still rely. More should I question thee, and more I must, Though more to know could not be more to trust: From whence thou cam'st, how tended on; but rest Unquestion'd welcome, and undoubted bless'd. Give me some help here, ho! If thou proceed As high as word, my deed shall match thy deed.

scenes.location: Rossillon. A room in the Countess's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Come on, sir; I shall now put you to the height of your breeding.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I will show myself highly fed and lowly taught. I know my business is but to the court.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: To the court! Why, what place make you special, when you put off that with such contempt? But to the court!

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Truly, madam, if God have lent a man any manners, he may easily put it off at court: he that cannot make a leg, put off's cap, kiss his hand, and say nothing, has neither leg, hands, lip, nor cap; and indeed such a fellow, to say precisely, were not for the court; but for me, I have an answer will serve all men.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Marry, that's a bountiful answer that fits all questions.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: It is like a barber's chair, that fits all buttocks-the pin-buttock, the quatch-buttock, the brawn-buttock, or any buttock.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Will your answer serve fit to all questions?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an attorney, as your French crown for your taffety punk, as Tib's rush for Tom's forefinger, as a pancake for Shrove-Tuesday, a morris for May-day, as the nail to his hole, the cuckold to his horn, as a scolding quean to a wrangling knave, as the nun's lip to the friar's mouth; nay, as the pudding to his skin.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Have you, I say, an answer of such fitness for all questions?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: From below your duke to beneath your constable, it will fit any question.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: It must be an answer of most monstrous size that must fit all demands.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: But a trifle neither, in good faith, if the learned should speak truth of it. Here it is, and all that belongs to't. Ask me if I am a courtier; it shall do you no harm to learn.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: To be young again, if we could: I will be a fool in question, hoping to be the wiser by your answer. I pray you, sir, are you a courtier?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: O Lord, sir! There's a simple putting off. More, more, a hundred of them.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Sir, I am a poor friend of yours, that loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: O Lord, sir! Thick, thick; spare not me.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: I think, sir, you can eat none of this homely meat.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: O Lord, sir! Nay, put me to't, I warrant you.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: You were lately whipp'd, sir, as I think.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: O Lord, sir! Spare not me.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Do you cry ‘O Lord, sir!' at your whipping, and ‘spare not me'? Indeed your ‘O Lord, sir!' is very sequent to your whipping. You would answer very well to a whipping, if you were but bound to't.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I ne'er had worse luck in my life in my ‘O Lord, sir!' I see things may serve long, but not serve ever.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: I play the noble housewife with the time, to entertain it so merrily with a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: O Lord, sir! Why, there't serves well again.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: An end, sir! To your business. Give Helen this, And urge her to a present answer back. Commend me to my kinsmen and my son. This is not much.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Not much commendation to them?

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Not much employment for you. You understand me?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Most fruitfully. I am there before my legs.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Haste you again.

scenes.location: Paris. The King's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: They say miracles are past; and we have our philosophical persons to make modern and familiar things supernatural and causeless. Hence is it that we make trifles of terrors, ensconcing ourselves into seeming knowledge when we should submit ourselves to an unknown fear.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Why, 'tis the rarest argument of wonder that hath shot out in our latter times.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: And so 'tis.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: To be relinquish'd of the artists,-

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: So I say; both of Galen and Paracelsus.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Of all the learned and authentic fellows,-

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Right; so I say.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: That gave him out incurable,-

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Why, there 'tis; so say I too.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Not to be helped.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Right; as 'twere a man assur'd of a-

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Uncertain life and sure death.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Just; you say well. So would I have said.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I may truly say, it is a novelty to the world.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: It is indeed; if you will have it in showing, you shall read it in what do you call there?

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: A showing of a heavenly effect in an earthly actor.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: That's it; I would have said the very same.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Why, your dolphin is not lustier; fore me, I speak in respect-

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Nay, 'tis strange, 'tis very strange; that is the brief and the tedious of it; and he's of a most facinerious spirit that will not acknowledge it to be the-

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Very hand of heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Ay, so I say.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: In a most weak-

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: And debile minister, great power, great transcendence, which should indeed give us a further use to be made than alone the recov'ry of the king, as to be-

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Generally thankful.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I would have said it; you say well. Here comes the king.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Lustique, as the Dutchman says. I'll like a maid the better, whilst I have a tooth in my head. Why, he's able to lead her a coranto.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: _Mor du vinager!_ is not this Helen?

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Fore God, I think so.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Go, call before me all the lords in court. Sit, my preserver, by thy patient's side, And with this healthful hand, whose banish'd sense Thou has repeal'd, a second time receive The confirmation of my promis'd gift, Which but attends thy naming. Fair maid, send forth thine eye. This youthful parcel Of noble bachelors stand at my bestowing, O'er whom both sovereign power and father's voice I have to use. Thy frank election make; Thou hast power to choose, and they none to forsake.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: To each of you one fair and virtuous mistress Fall, when love please! Marry, to each but one!

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I'd give bay curtal and his furniture My mouth no more were broken than these boys', And writ as little beard.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Peruse them well. Not one of those but had a noble father. She addresses her to a Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Gentlemen, Heaven hath through me restor'd the king to health.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: We understand it, and thank heaven for you.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I am a simple maid, and therein wealthiest That I protest I simply am a maid. Please it, your majesty, I have done already. The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me: "We blush that thou shouldst choose; but, be refused, Let the white death sit on thy cheek for ever, We'll ne'er come there again."

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Make choice; and, see, Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Now, Dian, from thy altar do I fly, And to imperial Love, that god most high, Do my sighs stream.  Sir, will you hear my suit?

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: And grant it.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Thanks, sir; all the rest is mute.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I had rather be in this choice than throw ames-ace for my life.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: The honour, sir, that flames in your fair eyes, Before I speak, too threat'ningly replies. Love make your fortunes twenty times above Her that so wishes, and her humble love!

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: No better, if you please.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: My wish receive, Which great Love grant; and so I take my leave.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Do all they deny her? An they were sons of mine I'd have them whipp'd; or I would send them to th' Turk to make eunuchs of.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Be not afraid that I your hand should take; I'll never do you wrong for your own sake. Blessing upon your vows, and in your bed Find fairer fortune, if you ever wed!

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: These boys are boys of ice, they'll none have her. Sure, they are bastards to the English; the French ne'er got 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: You are too young, too happy, and too good, To make yourself a son out of my blood.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Lord
dialogues.line: Fair one, I think not so.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: There's one grape yet. I am sure thy father drank wine. But if thou beest not an ass, I am a youth of fourteen; I have known thee already.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I dare not say I take you, but I give Me and my service, ever whilst I live, Into your guiding power. This is the man.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Why, then, young Bertram, take her; she's thy wife.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: My wife, my liege! I shall beseech your highness, In such a business give me leave to use The help of mine own eyes.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Know'st thou not, Bertram, What she has done for me?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Yes, my good lord, But never hope to know why I should marry her.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Thou know'st she has rais'd me from my sickly bed.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: But follows it, my lord, to bring me down Must answer for your raising? I know her well; She had her breeding at my father's charge: A poor physician's daughter my wife! Disdain Rather corrupt me ever!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: 'Tis only title thou disdain'st in her, the which I can build up. Strange is it that our bloods, Of colour, weight, and heat, pour'd all together, Would quite confound distinction, yet stands off In differences so mighty. If she be All that is virtuous, save what thou dislik'st, A poor physician's daughter,-thou dislik'st- Of virtue for the name. But do not so. From lowest place when virtuous things proceed, The place is dignified by the doer's deed. Where great additions swell's, and virtue none, It is a dropsied honour. Good alone Is good without a name; vileness is so: The property by what it is should go, Not by the title. She is young, wise, fair; In these to nature she's immediate heir; And these breed honour: that is honour's scorn Which challenges itself as honour's born, And is not like the sire. Honours thrive When rather from our acts we them derive Than our fore-goers. The mere word's a slave, Debauch'd on every tomb, on every grave A lying trophy, and as oft is dumb Where dust and damn'd oblivion is the tomb Of honour'd bones indeed. What should be said? If thou canst like this creature as a maid, I can create the rest. Virtue and she Is her own dower; honour and wealth from me.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I cannot love her, nor will strive to do 't.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Thou wrong'st thyself, if thou shouldst strive to choose.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: That you are well restor'd, my lord, I am glad. Let the rest go.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: My honour's at the stake, which to defeat, I must produce my power. Here, take her hand, Proud scornful boy, unworthy this good gift, That dost in vile misprision shackle up My love and her desert; that canst not dream We, poising us in her defective scale, Shall weigh thee to the beam; that wilt not know It is in us to plant thine honour where We please to have it grow. Check thy contempt; Obey our will, which travails in thy good; Believe not thy disdain, but presently Do thine own fortunes that obedient right Which both thy duty owes and our power claims; Or I will throw thee from my care for ever Into the staggers and the careless lapse Of youth and ignorance; both my revenge and hate Loosing upon thee in the name of justice, Without all terms of pity. Speak! Thine answer!

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Pardon, my gracious lord; for I submit My fancy to your eyes. When I consider What great creation, and what dole of honour Flies where you bid it, I find that she, which late Was in my nobler thoughts most base, is now The praised of the king; who, so ennobled, Is as 'twere born so.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Take her by the hand, And tell her she is thine; to whom I promise A counterpoise; if not to thy estate, A balance more replete.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I take her hand.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Good fortune and the favour of the king Smile upon this contract; whose ceremony Shall seem expedient on the now-born brief, And be perform'd tonight. The solemn feast Shall more attend upon the coming space, Expecting absent friends. As thou lov'st her, Thy love's to me religious; else, does err.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Do you hear, monsieur? A word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Your pleasure, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Your lord and master did well to make his recantation.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Recantation! My lord! My master!

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Ay. Is it not a language I speak?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: A most harsh one, and not to be understood without bloody succeeding. My master!

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Are you companion to the Count Rossillon?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: To any count; to all counts; to what is man.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: To what is count's man: count's master is of another style.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: You are too old, sir; let it satisfy you, you are too old.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I must tell thee, sirrah, I write man; to which title age cannot bring thee.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: What I dare too well do, I dare not do.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I did think thee, for two ordinaries, to be a pretty wise fellow; thou didst make tolerable vent of thy travel; it might pass. Yet the scarfs and the bannerets about thee did manifoldly dissuade me from believing thee a vessel of too great a burden. I have now found thee; when I lose thee again I care not. Yet art thou good for nothing but taking up, and that thou art scarce worth.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Hadst thou not the privilege of antiquity upon thee-

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Do not plunge thyself too far in anger, lest thou hasten thy trial; which if-Lord have mercy on thee for a hen! So, my good window of lattice, fare thee well; thy casement I need not open, for I look through thee. Give me thy hand.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: My lord, you give me most egregious indignity.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Ay, with all my heart; and thou art worthy of it.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I have not, my lord, deserv'd it.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Yes, good faith, every dram of it; and I will not bate thee a scruple.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Well, I shall be wiser.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Ev'n as soon as thou canst, for thou hast to pull at a smack o' th' contrary. If ever thou beest bound in thy scarf and beaten, thou shalt find what it is to be proud of thy bondage. I have a desire to hold my acquaintance with thee, or rather my knowledge, that I may say in the default, "He is a man I know."

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: My lord, you do me most insupportable vexation.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I would it were hell-pains for thy sake, and my poor doing eternal; for doing I am past, as I will by thee, in what motion age will give me leave.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Well, thou hast a son shall take this disgrace off me; scurvy, old, filthy, scurvy lord! Well, I must be patient; there is no fettering of authority. I'll beat him, by my life, if I can meet him with any convenience, an he were double and double a lord. I'll have no more pity of his age than I would have of-I'll beat him, and if I could but meet him again.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Sirrah, your lord and master's married; there's news for you; you have a new mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I most unfeignedly beseech your lordship to make some reservation of your wrongs. He is my good lord; whom I serve above is my master.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Who? God?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Ay, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: The devil it is that's thy master. Why dost thou garter up thy arms o' this fashion? Dost make hose of thy sleeves? Do other servants so? Thou wert best set thy lower part where thy nose stands. By mine honour, if I were but two hours younger, I'd beat thee. Methink'st thou art a general offence, and every man should beat thee. I think thou wast created for men to breathe themselves upon thee.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: This is hard and undeserved measure, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Go to, sir; you were beaten in Italy for picking a kernel out of a pomegranate; you are a vagabond, and no true traveller. You are more saucy with lords and honourable personages than the commission of your birth and virtue gives you heraldry. You are not worth another word, else I'd call you knave. I leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Good, very good, it is so then. Good, very good; let it be conceal'd awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Undone, and forfeited to cares for ever!

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: What's the matter, sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Although before the solemn priest I have sworn, I will not bed her.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: What, what, sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: O my Parolles, they have married me! I'll to the Tuscan wars, and never bed her.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: France is a dog-hole, and it no more merits The tread of a man's foot: to the wars!

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: There's letters from my mother; what th' import is I know not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Ay, that would be known. To th' wars, my boy, to th' wars! He wears his honour in a box unseen That hugs his kicky-wicky here at home, Spending his manly marrow in her arms, Which should sustain the bound and high curvet Of Mars's fiery steed. To other regions! France is a stable; we that dwell in't, jades, Therefore, to th' war!

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: It shall be so; I'll send her to my house, Acquaint my mother with my hate to her, And wherefore I am fled; write to the king That which I durst not speak. His present gift Shall furnish me to those Italian fields Where noble fellows strike. War is no strife To the dark house and the detested wife.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Will this caprichio hold in thee, art sure?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Go with me to my chamber and advise me. I'll send her straight away. Tomorrow I'll to the wars, she to her single sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Why, these balls bound; there's noise in it. 'Tis hard: A young man married is a man that's marr'd. Therefore away, and leave her bravely; go. The king has done you wrong; but hush 'tis so.

scenes.location: Paris. The King's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: My mother greets me kindly: is she well?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: She is not well, but yet she has her health; she's very merry, but yet she is not well. But thanks be given, she's very well, and wants nothing i' the world; but yet she is not well.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: If she be very well, what does she ail that she's not very well?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Truly, she's very well indeed, but for two things.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: What two things?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: One, that she's not in heaven, whither God send her quickly! The other, that she's in earth, from whence God send her quickly!

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Bless you, my fortunate lady!

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I hope, sir, I have your good will to have mine own good fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: You had my prayers to lead them on; and to keep them on, have them still. O, my knave how does my old lady?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: So that you had her wrinkles and I her money, I would she did as you say.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Why, I say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Marry, you are the wiser man; for many a man's tongue shakes out his master's undoing. To say nothing, to do nothing, to know nothing, and to have nothing, is to be a great part of your title; which is within a very little of nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Away! Thou art a knave.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: You should have said, sir, before a knave thou art a knave; that is before me thou art a knave. This had been truth, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Go to, thou art a witty fool; I have found thee.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Did you find me in yourself, sir? or were you taught to find me? The search, sir, was profitable; and much fool may you find in you, even to the world's pleasure and the increase of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: A good knave, i' faith, and well fed. Madam, my lord will go away tonight; A very serious business calls on him. The great prerogative and right of love, Which, as your due, time claims, he does acknowledge; But puts it off to a compell'd restraint; Whose want, and whose delay, is strew'd with sweets; Which they distil now in the curbed time, To make the coming hour o'erflow with joy And pleasure drown the brim.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: What's his will else?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: That you will take your instant leave o' the king, And make this haste as your own good proceeding, Strengthen'd with what apology you think May make it probable need.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: What more commands he?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: That, having this obtain'd, you presently Attend his further pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: In everything I wait upon his will.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I shall report it so.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I pray you. Come, sirrah.

scenes.location: Another room in the same.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: But I hope your lordship thinks not him a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Yes, my lord, and of very valiant approof.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: You have it from his own deliverance.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: And by other warranted testimony.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Then my dial goes not true; I took this lark for a bunting.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I do assure you, my lord, he is very great in knowledge, and accordingly valiant.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I have, then, sinned against his experience and transgressed against his valour; and my state that way is dangerous, since I cannot yet find in my heart to repent. Here he comes; I pray you make us friends; I will pursue the amity.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: These things shall be done, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Pray you, sir, who's his tailor?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: O, I know him well, I, sir; he, sir, is a good workman, a very good tailor.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Is she gone to the king?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: She is.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Will she away tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: As you'll have her.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I have writ my letters, casketed my treasure, Given order for our horses; and tonight, When I should take possession of the bride, End ere I do begin.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: A good traveller is something at the latter end of a dinner; but one that lies three-thirds and uses a known truth to pass a thousand nothings with, should be once heard and thrice beaten.- God save you, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Is there any unkindness between my lord and you, monsieur?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I know not how I have deserved to run into my lord's displeasure.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: You have made shift to run into 't, boots and spurs and all, like him that leapt into the custard; and out of it you'll run again, rather than suffer question for your residence.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: It may be you have mistaken him, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: And shall do so ever, though I took him at his prayers. Fare you well, my lord; and believe this of me, there can be no kernal in this light nut; the soul of this man is his clothes; trust him not in matter of heavy consequence; I have kept of them tame, and know their natures. Farewell, monsieur; I have spoken better of you than you have or will to deserve at my hand; but we must do good against evil.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: An idle lord, I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Why, do you not know him?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Yes, I do know him well; and common speech Gives him a worthy pass. Here comes my clog.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I have, sir, as I was commanded from you, Spoke with the king, and have procur'd his leave For present parting; only he desires Some private speech with you.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I shall obey his will. You must not marvel, Helen, at my course, Which holds not colour with the time, nor does The ministration and required office On my particular. Prepared I was not For such a business; therefore am I found So much unsettled: this drives me to entreat you; That presently you take your way for home, And rather muse than ask why I entreat you: For my respects are better than they seem; And my appointments have in them a need Greater than shows itself at the first view To you that know them not. This to my mother. 'Twill be two days ere I shall see you; so I leave you to your wisdom.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Sir, I can nothing say But that I am your most obedient servant.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Come, come, no more of that.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: And ever shall With true observance seek to eke out that Wherein toward me my homely stars have fail'd To equal my great fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Let that go. My haste is very great. Farewell; hie home.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Pray, sir, your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Well, what would you say?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I am not worthy of the wealth I owe; Nor dare I say 'tis mine, and yet it is; But, like a timorous thief, most fain would steal What law does vouch mine own.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: What would you have?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Something; and scarce so much; nothing indeed. I would not tell you what I would, my lord. Faith, yes, Strangers and foes do sunder and not kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I pray you, stay not, but in haste to horse.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I shall not break your bidding, good my lord. Where are my other men, monsieur? Farewell,

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Go thou toward home, where I will never come Whilst I can shake my sword or hear the drum. Away, and for our flight.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Bravely, coragio!

scenes.location: Florence. A room in the Duke's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: So that, from point to point, now have you heard The fundamental reasons of this war, Whose great decision hath much blood let forth, And more thirsts after.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Holy seems the quarrel Upon your Grace's part; black and fearful On the opposer.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Therefore we marvel much our cousin France Would, in so just a business, shut his bosom Against our borrowing prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Good my lord, The reasons of our state I cannot yield, But like a common and an outward man That the great figure of a council frames By self-unable motion; therefore dare not Say what I think of it, since I have found Myself in my incertain grounds to fail As often as I guess'd.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Be it his pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: But I am sure the younger of our nature, That surfeit on their ease, will day by day Come here for physic.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Welcome shall they be; And all the honours that can fly from us Shall on them settle. You know your places well; When better fall, for your avails they fell. Tomorrow to the field.

scenes.location: Rossillon. A room in the Countess's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: It hath happen'd all as I would have had it, save that he comes not along with her.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: By my troth, I take my young lord to be a very melancholy man.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: By what observance, I pray you?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Why, he will look upon his boot and sing; mend the ruff and sing; ask questions and sing; pick his teeth and sing. I know a man that had this trick of melancholy sold a goodly manor for a song.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Let me see what he writes, and when he means to come.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I have no mind to Isbel since I was at court. Our old lings and our Isbels o' th' country are nothing like your old ling and your Isbels o' th' court. The brains of my Cupid's knock'd out, and I begin to love, as an old man loves money, with no stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: What have we here?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: E'en that you have there.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: _I have sent you a daughter-in-law; she hath recovered the king and undone me. I have wedded her, not bedded her, and sworn to make the "not" eternal. You shall hear I am run away; know it before the report come. If there be breadth enough in the world, I will hold a long distance. My duty to you. Your unfortunate son,_

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: This is not well, rash and unbridled boy, To fly the favours of so good a king, To pluck his indignation on thy head By the misprizing of a maid too virtuous For the contempt of empire.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: O madam, yonder is heavy news within between two soldiers and my young lady.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: What is the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Nay, there is some comfort in the news, some comfort; your son will not be kill'd so soon as I thought he would.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Why should he be kill'd?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: So say I, madam, if he run away, as I hear he does; the danger is in standing to't; that's the loss of men, though it be the getting of children. Here they come will tell you more. For my part, I only hear your son was run away.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Save you, good madam.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Madam, my lord is gone, for ever gone.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Do not say so.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Think upon patience. Pray you, gentlemen,- I have felt so many quirks of joy and grief That the first face of neither on the start Can woman me unto 't. Where is my son, I pray you?

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Madam, he's gone to serve the Duke of Florence; We met him thitherward, for thence we came, And, after some despatch in hand at court, Thither we bend again.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Look on this letter, madam; here's my passport.  _When thou canst get the ring upon my finger, which never shall come off, and show me a child begotten of thy body that I am father to, then call me husband; but in such a "then" I write a "never"._ This is a dreadful sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Brought you this letter, gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Ay, madam; And for the contents' sake, are sorry for our pains.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: I pr'ythee, lady, have a better cheer; If thou engrossest all the griefs are thine, Thou robb'st me of a moiety. He was my son, But I do wash his name out of my blood, And thou art all my child. Towards Florence is he?

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Ay, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: And to be a soldier?

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Such is his noble purpose, and, believe't, The duke will lay upon him all the honour That good convenience claims.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Return you thither?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Ay, madam, with the swiftest wing of speed.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: _Till I have no wife, I have nothing in France._ 'Tis bitter.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Find you that there?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Ay, madam.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: 'Tis but the boldness of his hand haply, which his heart was not consenting to.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Nothing in France until he have no wife! There's nothing here that is too good for him But only she, and she deserves a lord That twenty such rude boys might tend upon, And call her hourly mistress. Who was with him?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: A servant only, and a gentleman which I have sometime known.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Parolles, was it not?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Ay, my good lady, he.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: A very tainted fellow, and full of wickedness. My son corrupts a well-derived nature With his inducement.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Indeed, good lady, The fellow has a deal of that too much, Which holds him much to have.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Y'are welcome, gentlemen. I will entreat you, when you see my son, To tell him that his sword can never win The honour that he loses: more I'll entreat you Written to bear along.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: We serve you, madam, In that and all your worthiest affairs.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Not so, but as we change our courtesies. Will you draw near?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: "Till I have no wife, I have nothing in France." Nothing in France until he has no wife! Thou shalt have none, Rossillon, none in France; Then hast thou all again. Poor lord, is't I That chase thee from thy country, and expose Those tender limbs of thine to the event Of the none-sparing war? And is it I That drive thee from the sportive court, where thou Wast shot at with fair eyes, to be the mark Of smoky muskets? O you leaden messengers, That ride upon the violent speed of fire, Fly with false aim; move the still-peering air, That sings with piercing; do not touch my lord. Whoever shoots at him, I set him there; Whoever charges on his forward breast, I am the caitiff that do hold him to't; And though I kill him not, I am the cause His death was so effected. Better 'twere I met the ravin lion when he roar'd With sharp constraint of hunger; better 'twere That all the miseries which nature owes Were mine at once.
