No; come thou home, Rossillon, Whence honour but of danger wins a scar, As oft it loses all. I will be gone; My being here it is that holds thee hence. Shall I stay here to do't? No, no, although The air of paradise did fan the house, And angels offic'd all. I will be gone, That pitiful rumour may report my flight To consolate thine ear. Come, night; end, day; For with the dark, poor thief, I'll steal away.

scenes.location: Florence. Before the Duke's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: The general of our horse thou art, and we, Great in our hope, lay our best love and credence Upon thy promising fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Sir, it is A charge too heavy for my strength; but yet We'll strive to bear it for your worthy sake To th'extreme edge of hazard.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Then go thou forth; And fortune play upon thy prosperous helm, As thy auspicious mistress!

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: This very day, Great Mars, I put myself into thy file; Make me but like my thoughts, and I shall prove A lover of thy drum, hater of love.

scenes.location: Rossillon. A room in the Countess's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Alas! and would you take the letter of her? Might you not know she would do as she has done, By sending me a letter? Read it again.

dialogues.speaker: Steward
dialogues.line: _I am Saint Jaques' pilgrim, thither gone. Ambitious love hath so in me offended That barefoot plod I the cold ground upon, With sainted vow my faults to have amended. Write, write, that from the bloody course of war My dearest master, your dear son, may hie. Bless him at home in peace, whilst I from far His name with zealous fervour sanctify. His taken labours bid him me forgive; I, his despiteful Juno, sent him forth From courtly friends, with camping foes to live, Where death and danger dog the heels of worth. He is too good and fair for death and me; Whom I myself embrace to set him free._

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Ah, what sharp stings are in her mildest words! Rynaldo, you did never lack advice so much As letting her pass so; had I spoke with her, I could have well diverted her intents, Which thus she hath prevented.

dialogues.speaker: Steward
dialogues.line: Pardon me, madam; If I had given you this at over-night, She might have been o'erta'en; and yet she writes Pursuit would be but vain.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: What angel shall Bless this unworthy husband? He cannot thrive, Unless her prayers, whom heaven delights to hear And loves to grant, reprieve him from the wrath Of greatest justice. Write, write, Rynaldo, To this unworthy husband of his wife; Let every word weigh heavy of her worth, That he does weigh too light; my greatest grief, Though little he do feel it, set down sharply. Dispatch the most convenient messenger. When haply he shall hear that she is gone He will return; and hope I may that she, Hearing so much, will speed her foot again, Led hither by pure love. Which of them both Is dearest to me I have no skill in sense To make distinction. Provide this messenger. My heart is heavy, and mine age is weak; Grief would have tears, and sorrow bids me speak.

scenes.location: Without the walls of Florence.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Nay, come; for if they do approach the city, we shall lose all the sight.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: They say the French count has done most honourable service.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: It is reported that he has taken their great'st commander, and that with his own hand he slew the duke's brother. We have lost our labour; they are gone a contrary way. Hark! you may know by their trumpets.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Come, let's return again, and suffice ourselves with the report of it. Well, Diana, take heed of this French earl; the honour of a maid is her name; and no legacy is so rich as honesty.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: I have told my neighbour how you have been solicited by a gentleman his companion.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: I know that knave; hang him! one Parolles; a filthy officer he is in those suggestions for the young earl. Beware of them, Diana; their promises, enticements, oaths, tokens, and all these engines of lust, are not the things they go under; many a maid hath been seduced by them; and the misery is, example, that so terrible shows in the wreck of maidenhood, cannot for all that dissuade succession, but that they are limed with the twigs that threaten them. I hope I need not to advise you further; but I hope your own grace will keep you where you are, though there were no further danger known but the modesty which is so lost.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: You shall not need to fear me.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: I hope so. Look, here comes a pilgrim. I know she will lie at my house; thither they send one another; I'll question her. God save you, pilgrim! Whither are bound?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: To Saint Jaques le Grand. Where do the palmers lodge, I do beseech you?

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: At the Saint Francis here, beside the port.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Is this the way?

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Ay, marry, is't. Hark you, they come this way. If you will tarry, holy pilgrim, But till the troops come by, I will conduct you where you shall be lodg'd; The rather for I think I know your hostess As ample as myself.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Is it yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: If you shall please so, pilgrim.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I thank you, and will stay upon your leisure.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: You came, I think, from France?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I did so.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Here you shall see a countryman of yours That has done worthy service.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: His name, I pray you.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: The Count Rossillon. Know you such a one?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: But by the ear, that hears most nobly of him; His face I know not.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Whatsome'er he is, He's bravely taken here. He stole from France, As 'tis reported, for the king had married him Against his liking. Think you it is so?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Ay, surely, mere the truth; I know his lady.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: There is a gentleman that serves the count Reports but coarsely of her.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Monsieur Parolles.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: O, I believe with him, In argument of praise, or to the worth Of the great count himself, she is too mean To have her name repeated; all her deserving Is a reserved honesty, and that I have not heard examin'd.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Alas, poor lady! 'Tis a hard bondage to become the wife Of a detesting lord.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Ay, right; good creature, wheresoe'er she is, Her heart weighs sadly. This young maid might do her A shrewd turn, if she pleas'd.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: How do you mean? Maybe the amorous count solicits her In the unlawful purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: He does indeed, And brokes with all that can in such a suit Corrupt the tender honour of a maid; But she is arm'd for him, and keeps her guard In honestest defence. Enter, with a drum and colours, a party of the Florentine army, Bertram and Parolles.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: The gods forbid else!

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: So, now they come. That is Antonio, the Duke's eldest son; That Escalus.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Which is the Frenchman?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: He; That with the plume; 'tis a most gallant fellow. I would he lov'd his wife; if he were honester He were much goodlier. Is't not a handsome gentleman?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I like him well.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: 'Tis pity he is not honest. Yond's that same knave That leads him to these places. Were I his lady I would poison that vile rascal.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Which is he?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: That jack-an-apes with scarfs. Why is he melancholy?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Perchance he's hurt i' the battle.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Lose our drum! Well.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: He's shrewdly vex'd at something. Look, he has spied us.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Marry, hang you!

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: And your courtesy, for a ring-carrier!

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: The troop is past. Come, pilgrim, I will bring you Where you shall host; of enjoin'd penitents There's four or five, to great Saint Jaques bound, Already at my house.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I humbly thank you. Please it this matron and this gentle maid To eat with us tonight; the charge and thanking Shall be for me; and, to requite you further, I will bestow some precepts of this virgin, Worthy the note.

dialogues.speaker: Both
dialogues.line: We'll take your offer kindly.

scenes.location: Camp before Florence.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Nay, good my lord, put him to't; let him have his way.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: If your lordship find him not a hilding, hold me no more in your respect.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: On my life, my lord, a bubble.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Do you think I am so far deceived in him?

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Believe it, my lord, in mine own direct knowledge, without any malice, but to speak of him as my kinsman, he's a most notable coward, an infinite and endless liar, an hourly promise-breaker, the owner of no one good quality worthy your lordship's entertainment.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: It were fit you knew him; lest, reposing too far in his virtue, which he hath not, he might at some great and trusty business, in a main danger fail you.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I would I knew in what particular action to try him.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: None better than to let him fetch off his drum, which you hear him so confidently undertake to do.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: I with a troop of Florentines will suddenly surprise him; such I will have whom I am sure he knows not from the enemy; we will bind and hoodwink him so that he shall suppose no other but that he is carried into the leaguer of the adversaries when we bring him to our own tents. Be but your lordship present at his examination; if he do not for the promise of his life, and in the highest compulsion of base fear, offer to betray you, and deliver all the intelligence in his power against you, and that with the divine forfeit of his soul upon oath, never trust my judgment in anything.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: O, for the love of laughter, let him fetch his drum; he says he has a stratagem for't. When your lordship sees the bottom of his success in't, and to what metal this counterfeit lump of ore will be melted, if you give him not John Drum's entertainment, your inclining cannot be removed. Here he comes.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: O, for the love of laughter, hinder not the honour of his design: let him fetch off his drum in any hand.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: How now, monsieur! This drum sticks sorely in your disposition.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: A pox on 't; let it go; 'tis but a drum.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: But a drum! Is't but a drum? A drum so lost! There was excellent command, to charge in with our horse upon our own wings, and to rend our own soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: That was not to be blam'd in the command of the service; it was a disaster of war that Caesar himself could not have prevented, if he had been there to command.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Well, we cannot greatly condemn our success: some dishonour we had in the loss of that drum, but it is not to be recovered.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: It might have been recovered.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: It might, but it is not now.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: It is to be recovered. But that the merit of service is seldom attributed to the true and exact performer, I would have that drum or another, or _hic jacet_.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Why, if you have a stomach, to't, monsieur, if you think your mystery in stratagem can bring this instrument of honour again into his native quarter, be magnanimous in the enterprise, and go on; I will grace the attempt for a worthy exploit; if you speed well in it, the duke shall both speak of it and extend to you what further becomes his greatness, even to the utmost syllable of your worthiness.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: By the hand of a soldier, I will undertake it.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: But you must not now slumber in it.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I'll about it this evening; and I will presently pen down my dilemmas, encourage myself in my certainty, put myself into my mortal preparation; and by midnight look to hear further from me.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: May I be bold to acquaint his grace you are gone about it?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I know not what the success will be, my lord, but the attempt I vow.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I know th'art valiant; and to the possibility of thy soldiership, will subscribe for thee. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I love not many words.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: No more than a fish loves water. Is not this a strange fellow, my lord, that so confidently seems to undertake this business, which he knows is not to be done; damns himself to do, and dares better be damn'd than to do't.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: You do not know him, my lord, as we do; certain it is that he will steal himself into a man's favour, and for a week escape a great deal of discoveries, but when you find him out, you have him ever after.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Why, do you think he will make no deed at all of this, that so seriously he does address himself unto?

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: None in the world; but return with an invention, and clap upon you two or three probable lies; but we have almost embossed him; you shall see his fall tonight; for indeed he is not for your lordship's respect.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: We'll make you some sport with the fox ere we case him. He was first smok'd by the old Lord Lafew; when his disguise and he is parted, tell me what a sprat you shall find him; which you shall see this very night.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: I must go look my twigs. He shall be caught.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Your brother, he shall go along with me.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: As't please your lordship. I'll leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Now will I lead you to the house, and show you The lass I spoke of.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: But you say she's honest.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: That's all the fault. I spoke with her but once, And found her wondrous cold, but I sent to her By this same coxcomb that we have i' the wind Tokens and letters which she did re-send, And this is all I have done. She's a fair creature; Will you go see her?

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: With all my heart, my lord.

scenes.location: Florence. A room in the Widow's house.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: If you misdoubt me that I am not she, I know not how I shall assure you further, But I shall lose the grounds I work upon.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Though my estate be fall'n, I was well born, Nothing acquainted with these businesses, And would not put my reputation now In any staining act.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Nor would I wish you. First give me trust, the count he is my husband, And what to your sworn counsel I have spoken Is so from word to word; and then you cannot, By the good aid that I of you shall borrow, Err in bestowing it.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: I should believe you, For you have show'd me that which well approves Y'are great in fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Take this purse of gold, And let me buy your friendly help thus far, Which I will over-pay, and pay again When I have found it. The count he woos your daughter Lays down his wanton siege before her beauty, Resolv'd to carry her; let her in fine consent, As we'll direct her how 'tis best to bear it. Now his important blood will naught deny That she'll demand; a ring the county wears, That downward hath succeeded in his house From son to son, some four or five descents Since the first father wore it. This ring he holds In most rich choice; yet, in his idle fire, To buy his will, it would not seem too dear, Howe'er repented after.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Now I see The bottom of your purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: You see it lawful then; it is no more But that your daughter, ere she seems as won, Desires this ring; appoints him an encounter; In fine, delivers me to fill the time, Herself most chastely absent. After, To marry her, I'll add three thousand crowns To what is pass'd already.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: I have yielded. Instruct my daughter how she shall persever, That time and place with this deceit so lawful May prove coherent. Every night he comes With musics of all sorts, and songs compos'd To her unworthiness: it nothing steads us To chide him from our eaves; for he persists As if his life lay on 't.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Why then tonight Let us assay our plot; which, if it speed, Is wicked meaning in a lawful deed, And lawful meaning in a lawful act, Where both not sin, and yet a sinful fact. But let's about it.

scenes.location: Without the Florentine camp.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: He can come no other way but by this hedge-corner. When you sally upon him, speak what terrible language you will; though you understand it not yourselves, no matter; for we must not seem to understand him, unless someone among us, whom we must produce for an interpreter.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Good captain, let me be th' interpreter.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Art not acquainted with him? Knows he not thy voice?

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: No sir, I warrant you.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: But what linsey-woolsey has thou to speak to us again?

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: E'en such as you speak to me.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: He must think us some band of strangers i' the adversary's entertainment. Now he hath a smack of all neighbouring languages, therefore we must every one be a man of his own fancy; not to know what we speak one to another, so we seem to know, is to know straight our purpose: choughs' language, gabble enough, and good enough. As for you, interpreter, you must seem very politic. But couch, ho! Here he comes; to beguile two hours in a sleep, and then to return and swear the lies he forges.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Ten o'clock. Within these three hours 'twill be time enough to go home. What shall I say I have done? It must be a very plausive invention that carries it. They begin to smoke me, and disgraces have of late knock'd too often at my door. I find my tongue is too foolhardy, but my heart hath the fear of Mars before it, and of his creatures, not daring the reports of my tongue.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: This is the first truth that e'er thine own tongue was guilty of.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: What the devil should move me to undertake the recovery of this drum, being not ignorant of the impossibility, and knowing I had no such purpose? I must give myself some hurts, and say I got them in exploit; yet slight ones will not carry it. They will say "Came you off with so little?" and great ones I dare not give. Wherefore, what's the instance? Tongue, I must put you into a butter-woman's mouth, and buy myself another of Bajazet's mule, if you prattle me into these perils.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Is it possible he should know what he is, and be that he is?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I would the cutting of my garments would serve the turn, or the breaking of my Spanish sword.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: We cannot afford you so.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Or the baring of my beard, and to say it was in stratagem.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: 'Twould not do.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Or to drown my clothes, and say I was stripped.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Hardly serve.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Though I swore I leap'd from the window of the citadel,-

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: How deep?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Thirty fathom.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Three great oaths would scarce make that be believed.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I would I had any drum of the enemy's; I would swear I recover'd it.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: You shall hear one anon.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: A drum now of the enemy's!

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: _Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo._

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: _Cargo, cargo, cargo, villianda par corbo, cargo._

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: O, ransom, ransom! Do not hide mine eyes.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: _Boskos thromuldo boskos._

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I know you are the Muskos' regiment, And I shall lose my life for want of language. If there be here German, or Dane, Low Dutch, Italian, or French, let him speak to me, I'll discover that which shall undo the Florentine.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: _Boskos vauvado._ I understand thee, and can speak thy tongue. _Kerelybonto._ Sir, Betake thee to thy faith, for seventeen poniards are at thy bosom.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: O!

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: O, pray, pray, pray! _Manka revania dulche._

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: _Oscorbidulchos volivorco._

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: The General is content to spare thee yet; And, hoodwink'd as thou art, will lead thee on To gather from thee. Haply thou mayst inform Something to save thy life.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: O, let me live, And all the secrets of our camp I'll show, Their force, their purposes; nay, I'll speak that Which you will wonder at.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: But wilt thou faithfully?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: If I do not, damn me.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: _Acordo linta._ Come on; thou art granted space. A short alarum within.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Go tell the Count Rossillon and my brother We have caught the woodcock, and will keep him muffled Till we do hear from them.

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: Captain, I will.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: 'A will betray us all unto ourselves; Inform on that.

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: So I will, sir.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Till then I'll keep him dark, and safely lock'd.

scenes.location: Florence. A room in the Widow's house.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: They told me that your name was Fontybell.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: No, my good lord, Diana.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Titled goddess; And worth it, with addition! But, fair soul, In your fine frame hath love no quality? If the quick fire of youth light not your mind, You are no maiden but a monument; When you are dead, you should be such a one As you are now; for you are cold and stern, And now you should be as your mother was When your sweet self was got.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: She then was honest.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: So should you be.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: No. My mother did but duty; such, my lord, As you owe to your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: No more a' that! I pr'ythee do not strive against my vows; I was compell'd to her; but I love thee By love's own sweet constraint, and will for ever Do thee all rights of service.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Ay, so you serve us Till we serve you; but when you have our roses, You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves, And mock us with our bareness.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: How have I sworn?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: 'Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth, But the plain single vow that is vow'd true. What is not holy, that we swear not by, But take the highest to witness: then, pray you, tell me, If I should swear by Jove's great attributes I lov'd you dearly, would you believe my oaths When I did love you ill? This has no holding, To swear by him whom I protest to love That I will work against him. Therefore your oaths Are words and poor conditions; but unseal'd,- At least in my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Change it, change it. Be not so holy-cruel. Love is holy; And my integrity ne'er knew the crafts That you do charge men with. Stand no more off, But give thyself unto my sick desires, Who then recovers. Say thou art mine, and ever My love as it begins shall so persever.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: I see that men make hopes in such a case, That we'll forsake ourselves. Give me that ring.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I'll lend it thee, my dear, but have no power To give it from me.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Will you not, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: It is an honour 'longing to our house, Bequeathed down from many ancestors, Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world In me to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Mine honour's such a ring; My chastity's the jewel of our house, Bequeathed down from many ancestors, Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world In me to lose. Thus your own proper wisdom Brings in the champion honour on my part Against your vain assault.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Here, take my ring; My house, mine honour, yea, my life be thine, And I'll be bid by thee.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: When midnight comes, knock at my chamber window; I'll order take my mother shall not hear. Now will I charge you in the band of truth, When you have conquer'd my yet maiden-bed, Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me. My reasons are most strong; and you shall know them When back again this ring shall be deliver'd; And on your finger in the night, I'll put Another ring, that what in time proceeds May token to the future our past deeds. Adieu till then; then fail not. You have won A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: For which live long to thank both heaven and me! You may so in the end. My mother told me just how he would woo, As if she sat in's heart. She says all men Have the like oaths. He had sworn to marry me When his wife's dead; therefore I'll lie with him When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid, Marry that will, I live and die a maid. Only, in this disguise, I think't no sin To cozen him that would unjustly win.

scenes.location: The Florentine camp.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: You have not given him his mother's letter?

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: I have deliv'red it an hour since; there is something in't that stings his nature; for on the reading it, he chang'd almost into another man.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: He has much worthy blame laid upon him for shaking off so good a wife and so sweet a lady.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Especially he hath incurred the everlasting displeasure of the king, who had even tun'd his bounty to sing happiness to him. I will tell you a thing, but you shall let it dwell darkly with you.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: When you have spoken it, 'tis dead, and I am the grave of it.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: He hath perverted a young gentlewoman here in Florence, of a most chaste renown, and this night he fleshes his will in the spoil of her honour; he hath given her his monumental ring, and thinks himself made in the unchaste composition.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Now, God delay our rebellion! As we are ourselves, what things are we!

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Merely our own traitors. And as in the common course of all treasons, we still see them reveal themselves till they attain to their abhorr'd ends; so he that in this action contrives against his own nobility, in his proper stream, o'erflows himself.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Is it not meant damnable in us to be trumpeters of our unlawful intents? We shall not then have his company tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Not till after midnight; for he is dieted to his hour.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: That approaches apace. I would gladly have him see his company anatomized, that he might take a measure of his own judgments, wherein so curiously he had set this counterfeit.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: We will not meddle with him till he come; for his presence must be the whip of the other.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: In the meantime, what hear you of these wars?

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: I hear there is an overture of peace.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Nay, I assure you, a peace concluded.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: What will Count Rossillon do then? Will he travel higher, or return again into France?

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: I perceive by this demand, you are not altogether of his council.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Let it be forbid, sir! So should I be a great deal of his act.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Sir, his wife some two months since fled from his house. Her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Jaques le Grand; which holy undertaking with most austere sanctimony she accomplished; and there residing, the tenderness of her nature became as a prey to her grief; in fine, made a groan of her last breath, and now she sings in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: How is this justified?

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: The stronger part of it by her own letters, which makes her story true, even to the point of her death. Her death itself, which could not be her office to say is come, was faithfully confirm'd by the rector of the place.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Hath the count all this intelligence?

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Ay, and the particular confirmations, point from point, to the full arming of the verity.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: I am heartily sorry that he'll be glad of this.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: How mightily sometimes we make us comforts of our losses!

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: And how mightily some other times we drown our gain in tears! The great dignity that his valour hath here acquir'd for him shall at home be encountered with a shame as ample.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good and ill together; our virtues would be proud if our faults whipped them not; and our crimes would despair if they were not cherish'd by our virtues. How now? Where's your master?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: He met the duke in the street, sir; of whom he hath taken a solemn leave: his lordship will next morning for France. The duke hath offered him letters of commendations to the king.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: They shall be no more than needful there, if they were more than they can commend.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: They cannot be too sweet for the king's tartness. Here's his lordship now. How now, my lord, is't not after midnight?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I have tonight despatch'd sixteen businesses, a month's length apiece; by an abstract of success: I have congied with the duke, done my adieu with his nearest; buried a wife, mourn'd for her, writ to my lady mother I am returning, entertained my convoy, and between these main parcels of despatch effected many nicer needs: the last was the greatest, but that I have not ended yet.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: If the business be of any difficulty and this morning your departure hence, it requires haste of your lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I mean the business is not ended, as fearing to hear of it hereafter. But shall we have this dialogue between the Fool and the Soldier? Come, bring forth this counterfeit module has deceiv'd me like a double-meaning prophesier.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Bring him forth. Has sat i' the stocks all night, poor gallant knave.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: No matter; his heels have deserv'd it, in usurping his spurs so long. How does he carry himself?

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: I have told your lordship already; the stocks carry him. But to answer you as you would be understood: he weeps like a wench that had shed her milk; he hath confessed himself to Morgan, whom he supposes to be a friar, from the time of his remembrance to this very instant disaster of his setting i' the stocks. And what think you he hath confessed?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Nothing of me, has he?

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: His confession is taken, and it shall be read to his face; if your lordship be in't, as I believe you are, you must have the patience to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: A plague upon him! muffled! he can say nothing of me; hush, hush!

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Hoodman comes! _Portotartarossa._

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: He calls for the tortures. What will you say without 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I will confess what I know without constraint. If ye pinch me like a pasty I can say no more.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: _Bosko chimurcho._

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: _Boblibindo chicurmurco._

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: You are a merciful general. Our general bids you answer to what I shall ask you out of a note.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: And truly, as I hope to live.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: ‘First demand of him how many horse the duke is strong.' What say you to that?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Five or six thousand; but very weak and unserviceable: the troops are all scattered, and the commanders very poor rogues, upon my reputation and credit, and as I hope to live.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Shall I set down your answer so?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Do. I'll take the sacrament on 't, how and which way you will.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: All's one to him. What a past-saving slave is this!

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: You are deceived, my lord; this is Monsieur Parolles, the gallant militarist (that was his own phrase), that had the whole theoric of war in the knot of his scarf, and the practice in the chape of his dagger.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: I will never trust a man again for keeping his sword clean, nor believe he can have everything in him by wearing his apparel neatly.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Well, that's set down.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: ‘Five or six thousand horse' I said-I will say true-or thereabouts, set down,-for I'll speak truth.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: He's very near the truth in this.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: But I con him no thanks for't in the nature he delivers it.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Poor rogues, I pray you say.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Well, that's set down.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I humbly thank you, sir; a truth's a truth, the rogues are marvellous poor.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: ‘Demand of him of what strength they are a-foot.' What say you to that?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: By my troth, sir, if I were to live this present hour, I will tell true. Let me see: Spurio, a hundred and fifty, Sebastian, so many; Corambus, so many; Jaques, so many; Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowick, and Gratii, two hundred fifty each; mine own company, Chitopher, Vaumond, Bentii, two hundred fifty each: so that the muster-file, rotten and sound, upon my life, amounts not to fifteen thousand poll; half of the which dare not shake the snow from off their cassocks lest they shake themselves to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: What shall be done to him?

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Nothing, but let him have thanks. Demand of him my condition, and what credit I have with the duke.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Well, that's set down. ‘You shall demand of him whether one Captain Dumaine be i' the camp, a Frenchman; what his reputation is with the duke, what his valour, honesty and expertness in wars; or whether he thinks it were not possible with well-weighing sums of gold to corrupt him to a revolt.' What say you to this? What do you know of it?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I beseech you, let me answer to the particular of the inter'gatories. Demand them singly.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Do you know this Captain Dumaine?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I know him: he was a botcher's 'prentice in Paris, from whence he was whipped for getting the shrieve's fool with child, a dumb innocent that could not say him nay.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Nay, by your leave, hold your hands; though I know his brains are forfeit to the next tile that falls.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Well, is this captain in the Duke of Florence's camp?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Upon my knowledge, he is, and lousy.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Nay, look not so upon me; we shall hear of your lordship anon.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: What is his reputation with the duke?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: The duke knows him for no other but a poor officer of mine, and writ to me this other day to turn him out o' the band. I think I have his letter in my pocket.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Marry, we'll search.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: In good sadness, I do not know; either it is there or it is upon a file, with the duke's other letters, in my tent.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Here 'tis; here's a paper; shall I read it to you?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I do not know if it be it or no.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Our interpreter does it well.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Excellently.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: _Dian, the Count's a fool, and full of gold._

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: That is not the duke's letter, sir; that is an advertisement to a proper maid in Florence, one Diana, to take heed of the allurement of one Count Rossillon, a foolish idle boy, but for all that very ruttish. I pray you, sir, put it up again.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Nay, I'll read it first by your favour.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: My meaning in't, I protest, was very honest in the behalf of the maid; for I knew the young count to be a dangerous and lascivious boy, who is a whale to virginity, and devours up all the fry it finds.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Damnable both sides rogue!

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: _When he swears oaths, bid him drop gold, and take it; After he scores, he never pays the score. Half won is match well made; match, and well make it; He ne'er pays after-debts, take it before. And say a soldier, ‘Dian,' told thee this: Men are to mell with, boys are not to kiss; For count of this, the count's a fool, I know it, Who pays before, but not when he does owe it. Thine, as he vow'd to thee in thine ear,_

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: He shall be whipped through the army with this rhyme in's forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: This is your devoted friend, sir, the manifold linguist, and the armipotent soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I could endure anything before but a cat, and now he's a cat to me.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: I perceive, sir, by our general's looks we shall be fain to hang you.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: My life, sir, in any case. Not that I am afraid to die, but that, my offences being many, I would repent out the remainder of nature. Let me live, sir, in a dungeon, i' the stocks, or anywhere, so I may live.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: We'll see what may be done, so you confess freely. Therefore, once more to this Captain Dumaine: you have answer'd to his reputation with the duke, and to his valour. What is his honesty?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: He will steal, sir, an egg out of a cloister: for rapes and ravishments he parallels Nessus. He professes not keeping of oaths; in breaking them he is stronger than Hercules. He will lie, sir, with such volubility that you would think truth were a fool: drunkenness is his best virtue, for he will be swine-drunk, and in his sleep he does little harm, save to his bedclothes about him; but they know his conditions and lay him in straw. I have but little more to say, sir, of his honesty; he has everything that an honest man should not have; what an honest man should have, he has nothing.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: I begin to love him for this.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: For this description of thine honesty? A pox upon him for me, he's more and more a cat.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: What say you to his expertness in war?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Faith, sir, has led the drum before the English tragedians,-to belie him I will not,-and more of his soldiership I know not, except in that country he had the honour to be the officer at a place there called Mile-end, to instruct for the doubling of files. I would do the man what honour I can, but of this I am not certain.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: He hath out-villain'd villainy so far that the rarity redeems him.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: A pox on him! He's a cat still.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: His qualities being at this poor price, I need not to ask you if gold will corrupt him to revolt.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Sir, for a quart d'ecu he will sell the fee-simple of his salvation, the inheritance of it, and cut the entail from all remainders, and a perpetual succession for it perpetually.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: What's his brother, the other Captain Dumaine?

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Why does he ask him of me?

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: What's he?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: E'en a crow o' the same nest; not altogether so great as the first in goodness, but greater a great deal in evil. He excels his brother for a coward, yet his brother is reputed one of the best that is. In a retreat he outruns any lackey; marry, in coming on he has the cramp.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: If your life be saved, will you undertake to betray the Florentine?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Ay, and the captain of his horse, Count Rossillon.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: I'll whisper with the general, and know his pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I'll no more drumming; a plague of all drums! Only to seem to deserve well, and to beguile the supposition of that lascivious young boy the count, have I run into this danger: yet who would have suspected an ambush where I was taken?

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: There is no remedy, sir, but you must die. The general says you that have so traitorously discovered the secrets of your army, and made such pestiferous reports of men very nobly held, can serve the world for no honest use; therefore you must die. Come, headsman, off with his head.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: O Lord! sir, let me live, or let me see my death.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: That shall you, and take your leave of all your friends. So, look about you; know you any here?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Good morrow, noble captain.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: God bless you, Captain Parolles.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: God save you, noble captain.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord Lafew? I am for France.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Good Captain, will you give me a copy of the sonnet you writ to Diana in behalf of the Count Rossillon? And I were not a very coward I'd compel it of you; but fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: You are undone, captain: all but your scarf; that has a knot on't yet.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Who cannot be crushed with a plot?

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: If you could find out a country where but women were that had received so much shame, you might begin an impudent nation. Fare ye well, sir. I am for France too; we shall speak of you there.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Yet am I thankful. If my heart were great 'Twould burst at this. Captain I'll be no more, But I will eat, and drink, and sleep as soft As captain shall. Simply the thing I am Shall make me live. Who knows himself a braggart, Let him fear this; for it will come to pass That every braggart shall be found an ass. Rust, sword; cool, blushes; and, Parolles live Safest in shame; being fool'd, by foolery thrive. There's place and means for every man alive. I'll after them.

scenes.location: Florence. A room in the Widow's house.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: That you may well perceive I have not wrong'd you One of the greatest in the Christian world Shall be my surety; fore whose throne 'tis needful, Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneel. Time was I did him a desired office, Dear almost as his life; which gratitude Through flinty Tartar's bosom would peep forth, And answer thanks. I duly am inform'd His grace is at Marseilles; to which place We have convenient convoy. You must know I am supposed dead. The army breaking, My husband hies him home, where, heaven aiding, And by the leave of my good lord the king, We'll be before our welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Gentle madam, You never had a servant to whose trust Your business was more welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Nor you, mistress, Ever a friend whose thoughts more truly labour To recompense your love. Doubt not but heaven Hath brought me up to be your daughter's dower, As it hath fated her to be my motive And helper to a husband. But, O strange men! That can such sweet use make of what they hate, When saucy trusting of the cozen'd thoughts Defiles the pitchy night; so lust doth play With what it loathes, for that which is away. But more of this hereafter. You, Diana, Under my poor instructions yet must suffer Something in my behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Let death and honesty Go with your impositions, I am yours Upon your will to suffer.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Yet, I pray you; But with the word the time will bring on summer, When briers shall have leaves as well as thorns, And be as sweet as sharp. We must away; Our waggon is prepar'd, and time revives us. All's well that ends well; still the fine's the crown. Whate'er the course, the end is the renown.

scenes.location: Rossillon. A room in the Countess's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: No, no, no, your son was misled with a snipt-taffeta fellow there, whose villanous saffron would have made all the unbak'd and doughy youth of a nation in his colour. Your daughter-in-law had been alive at this hour, and your son here at home, more advanc'd by the king than by that red-tail'd humble-bee I speak of.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: I would I had not known him; it was the death of the most virtuous gentlewoman that ever nature had praise for creating. If she had partaken of my flesh and cost me the dearest groans of a mother, I could not have owed her a more rooted love.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: 'Twas a good lady, 'twas a good lady. We may pick a thousand salads ere we light on such another herb.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Indeed, sir, she was the sweet marjoram of the salad, or, rather, the herb of grace.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: They are not herbs, you knave; they are nose-herbs.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I am no great Nebuchadnezzar, sir; I have not much skill in grass.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Whether dost thou profess thyself,-a knave or a fool?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: A fool, sir, at a woman's service, and a knave at a man's.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Your distinction?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I would cozen the man of his wife, and do his service.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: So you were a knave at his service indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: And I would give his wife my bauble, sir, to do her service.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I will subscribe for thee; thou art both knave and fool.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: At your service.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: No, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Why, sir, if I cannot serve you, I can serve as great a prince as you are.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Who's that? a Frenchman?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Faith, sir, 'a has an English name; but his phisnomy is more hotter in France than there.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: What prince is that?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: The black prince, sir; alias the prince of darkness; alias the devil.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Hold thee, there's my purse. I give thee not this to suggest thee from thy master thou talk'st of; serve him still.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I am a woodland fellow, sir, that always loved a great fire, and the master I speak of ever keeps a good fire. But sure he is the prince of the world; let his nobility remain in's court. I am for the house with the narrow gate, which I take to be too little for pomp to enter: some that humble themselves may, but the many will be too chill and tender, and they'll be for the flow'ry way that leads to the broad gate and the great fire.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Go thy ways, I begin to be a-weary of thee; and I tell thee so before, because I would not fall out with thee. Go thy ways; let my horses be well look'd to, without any tricks.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: If I put any tricks upon 'em, sir, they shall be jades' tricks, which are their own right by the law of nature.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: A shrewd knave, and an unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: So he is. My lord that's gone made himself much sport out of him; by his authority he remains here, which he thinks is a patent for his sauciness; and indeed he has no pace, but runs where he will.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I like him well; 'tis not amiss. And I was about to tell you, since I heard of the good lady's death, and that my lord your son was upon his return home, I moved the king my master to speak in the behalf of my daughter; which, in the minority of them both, his majesty out of a self-gracious remembrance did first propose. His highness hath promis'd me to do it; and, to stop up the displeasure he hath conceived against your son, there is no fitter matter. How does your ladyship like it?

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: With very much content, my lord, and I wish it happily effected.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: His highness comes post from Marseilles, of as able body as when he number'd thirty; he will be here tomorrow, or I am deceived by him that in such intelligence hath seldom fail'd.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: It rejoices me that I hope I shall see him ere I die. I have letters that my son will be here tonight. I shall beseech your lordship to remain with me till they meet together.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Madam, I was thinking with what manners I might safely be admitted.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: You need but plead your honourable privilege.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Lady, of that I have made a bold charter; but, I thank my God, it holds yet.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: O madam, yonder's my lord your son with a patch of velvet on's face; whether there be a scar under't or no, the velvet knows; but 'tis a goodly patch of velvet. His left cheek is a cheek of two pile and a half, but his right cheek is worn bare.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: A scar nobly got, or a noble scar, is a good livery of honour; so belike is that.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: But it is your carbonado'd face.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Let us go see your son, I pray you. I long to talk with the young noble soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Faith, there's a dozen of 'em, with delicate fine hats, and most courteous feathers, which bow the head and nod at every man.

scenes.location: Marseilles. A street.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: But this exceeding posting day and night Must wear your spirits low. We cannot help it. But since you have made the days and nights as one, To wear your gentle limbs in my affairs, Be bold you do so grow in my requital As nothing can unroot you. In happy time;- This man may help me to his majesty's ear, If he would spend his power. God save you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: And you.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Sir, I have seen you in the court of France.

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: I have been sometimes there.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I do presume, sir, that you are not fallen From the report that goes upon your goodness; And therefore, goaded with most sharp occasions, Which lay nice manners by, I put you to The use of your own virtues, for the which I shall continue thankful.

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: What's your will?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: That it will please you To give this poor petition to the king, And aid me with that store of power you have To come into his presence.

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: The king's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: Not here, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: Not indeed. He hence remov'd last night, and with more haste Than is his use.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: Lord, how we lose our pains!

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: All's well that ends well yet, Though time seem so adverse and means unfit. I do beseech you, whither is he gone?

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: Marry, as I take it, to Rossillon; Whither I am going.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: I do beseech you, sir, Since you are like to see the king before me, Commend the paper to his gracious hand, Which I presume shall render you no blame, But rather make you thank your pains for it. I will come after you with what good speed Our means will make us means.

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: This I'll do for you.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: And you shall find yourself to be well thank'd, Whate'er falls more. We must to horse again. Go, go, provide.

scenes.location: Rossillon. The inner court of the Countess's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Good Monsieur Lavache, give my Lord Lafew this letter; I have ere now, sir, been better known to you, when I have held familiarity with fresher clothes; but I am now, sir, muddied in Fortune's mood, and smell somewhat strong of her strong displeasure.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Truly, Fortune's displeasure is but sluttish, if it smell so strongly as thou speak'st of. I will henceforth eat no fish of Fortune's buttering. Pr'ythee, allow the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Nay, you need not to stop your nose, sir. I spake but by a metaphor.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Indeed, sir, if your metaphor stink, I will stop my nose, or against any man's metaphor. Pr'ythee, get thee further.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Pray you, sir, deliver me this paper.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Foh, pr'ythee stand away. A paper from Fortune's close-stool to give to a nobleman! Look here he comes himself. Here is a pur of Fortune's, sir, or of Fortune's cat, but not a musk-cat, that has fallen into the unclean fishpond of her displeasure, and as he says, is muddied withal. Pray you, sir, use the carp as you may, for he looks like a poor, decayed, ingenious, foolish, rascally knave. I do pity his distress in my similes of comfort, and leave him to your lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: My lord, I am a man whom Fortune hath cruelly scratch'd.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: And what would you have me to do? 'Tis too late to pare her nails now. Wherein have you played the knave with Fortune that she should scratch you, who of herself is a good lady, and would not have knaves thrive long under her? There's a quart d'ecu for you. Let the justices make you and Fortune friends; I am for other business.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I beseech your honour to hear me one single word.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: You beg a single penny more. Come, you shall ha't; save your word.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: My name, my good lord, is Parolles.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: You beg more than word then. Cox my passion! Give me your hand. How does your drum?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: O my good lord, you were the first that found me.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Was I, in sooth? And I was the first that lost thee.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: It lies in you, my lord, to bring me in some grace, for you did bring me out.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Out upon thee, knave! dost thou put upon me at once both the office of God and the devil? One brings thee in grace, and the other brings thee out. The king's coming; I know by his trumpets. Sirrah, inquire further after me. I had talk of you last night; though you are a fool and a knave, you shall eat. Go to; follow.

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I praise God for you.

scenes.location: The same. A room in the Countess's palace.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: We lost a jewel of her, and our esteem Was made much poorer by it; but your son, As mad in folly, lack'd the sense to know Her estimation home.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: 'Tis past, my liege, And I beseech your majesty to make it Natural rebellion, done i' the blaze of youth, When oil and fire, too strong for reason's force, O'erbears it and burns on.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: My honour'd lady, I have forgiven and forgotten all, Though my revenges were high bent upon him, And watch'd the time to shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: This I must say,- But first, I beg my pardon,-the young lord Did to his majesty, his mother, and his lady, Offence of mighty note; but to himself The greatest wrong of all. He lost a wife Whose beauty did astonish the survey Of richest eyes; whose words all ears took captive; Whose dear perfection hearts that scorn'd to serve Humbly call'd mistress.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Praising what is lost Makes the remembrance dear. Well, call him hither; We are reconcil'd, and the first view shall kill All repetition. Let him not ask our pardon; The nature of his great offence is dead, And deeper than oblivion do we bury Th' incensing relics of it. Let him approach A stranger, no offender; and inform him So 'tis our will he should.

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: I shall, my liege.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What says he to your daughter? Have you spoke?

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: All that he is hath reference to your highness.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Then shall we have a match. I have letters sent me That sets him high in fame.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: He looks well on 't.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I am not a day of season, For thou mayst see a sunshine and a hail In me at once. But to the brightest beams Distracted clouds give way; so stand thou forth; The time is fair again.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: My high-repented blames Dear sovereign, pardon to me.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: All is whole. Not one word more of the consumed time. Let's take the instant by the forward top; For we are old, and on our quick'st decrees Th'inaudible and noiseless foot of time Steals ere we can effect them. You remember The daughter of this lord?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Admiringly, my liege. At first I stuck my choice upon her, ere my heart Durst make too bold herald of my tongue: Where the impression of mine eye infixing, Contempt his scornful perspective did lend me, Which warp'd the line of every other favour, Scorn'd a fair colour, or express'd it stolen, Extended or contracted all proportions To a most hideous object. Thence it came That she whom all men prais'd, and whom myself, Since I have lost, have lov'd, was in mine eye The dust that did offend it.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Well excus'd: That thou didst love her, strikes some scores away From the great compt: but love that comes too late, Like a remorseful pardon slowly carried, To the great sender turns a sour offence, Crying, That's good that's gone. Our rash faults Make trivial price of serious things we have, Not knowing them until we know their grave. Oft our displeasures, to ourselves unjust, Destroy our friends, and after weep their dust: Our own love waking cries to see what's done, While shameful hate sleeps out the afternoon. Be this sweet Helen's knell, and now forget her. Send forth your amorous token for fair Maudlin. The main consents are had, and here we'll stay To see our widower's second marriage-day.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Which better than the first, O dear heaven, bless! Or, ere they meet, in me, O nature, cesse!

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Come on, my son, in whom my house's name Must be digested; give a favour from you, To sparkle in the spirits of my daughter, That she may quickly come. By my old beard, And ev'ry hair that's on 't, Helen that's dead Was a sweet creature: such a ring as this, The last that e'er I took her leave at court, I saw upon her finger.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Hers it was not.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Now, pray you, let me see it; for mine eye, While I was speaking, oft was fasten'd to it. This ring was mine; and when I gave it Helen I bade her, if her fortunes ever stood Necessitied to help, that by this token I would relieve her. Had you that craft to 'reave her Of what should stead her most?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: My gracious sovereign, Howe'er it pleases you to take it so, The ring was never hers.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Son, on my life, I have seen her wear it; and she reckon'd it At her life's rate.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I am sure I saw her wear it.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: You are deceiv'd, my lord; she never saw it. In Florence was it from a casement thrown me, Wrapp'd in a paper, which contain'd the name Of her that threw it. Noble she was, and thought I stood engag'd; but when I had subscrib'd To mine own fortune, and inform'd her fully I could not answer in that course of honour As she had made the overture, she ceas'd, In heavy satisfaction, and would never Receive the ring again.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Plutus himself, That knows the tinct and multiplying medicine, Hath not in nature's mystery more science Than I have in this ring. 'Twas mine, 'twas Helen's, Whoever gave it you. Then if you know That you are well acquainted with yourself, Confess 'twas hers, and by what rough enforcement You got it from her. She call'd the saints to surety That she would never put it from her finger Unless she gave it to yourself in bed, Where you have never come, or sent it us Upon her great disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: She never saw it.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Thou speak'st it falsely, as I love mine honour, And mak'st conjectural fears to come into me Which I would fain shut out. If it should prove That thou art so inhuman,-'twill not prove so: And yet I know not, thou didst hate her deadly. And she is dead; which nothing but to close Her eyes myself, could win me to believe More than to see this ring. Take him away. My fore-past proofs, howe'er the matter fall, Shall tax my fears of little vanity, Having vainly fear'd too little. Away with him. We'll sift this matter further.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: If you shall prove This ring was ever hers, you shall as easy Prove that I husbanded her bed in Florence, Where she yet never was.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I am wrapp'd in dismal thinkings.

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: Gracious sovereign, Whether I have been to blame or no, I know not: Here's a petition from a Florentine, Who hath for four or five removes come short To tender it herself. I undertook it, Vanquish'd thereto by the fair grace and speech Of the poor suppliant, who by this, I know, Is here attending: her business looks in her With an importing visage, and she told me In a sweet verbal brief, it did concern Your highness with herself.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: _Upon his many protestations to marry me when his wife was dead, I blush to say it, he won me. Now is the Count Rossillon a widower; his vows are forfeited to me, and my honour's paid to him. He stole from Florence, taking no leave, and I follow him to his country for justice. Grant it me, O king, in you it best lies; otherwise a seducer flourishes, and a poor maid is undone._

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I will buy me a son-in-law in a fair, and toll for this. I'll none of him.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: The heavens have thought well on thee, Lafew, To bring forth this discovery. Seek these suitors. Go speedily, and bring again the count. I am afeard the life of Helen, lady, Was foully snatch'd.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Now, justice on the doers!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I wonder, sir, since wives are monsters to you, And that you fly them as you swear them lordship, Yet you desire to marry. What woman's that?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: I am, my lord, a wretched Florentine, Derived from the ancient Capilet; My suit, as I do understand, you know, And therefore know how far I may be pitied.

dialogues.speaker: Widow
dialogues.line: I am her mother, sir, whose age and honour Both suffer under this complaint we bring, And both shall cease, without your remedy.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Come hither, count; do you know these women?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: My lord, I neither can nor will deny But that I know them. Do they charge me further?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Why do you look so strange upon your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: She's none of mine, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: If you shall marry, You give away this hand, and that is mine, You give away heaven's vows, and those are mine, You give away myself, which is known mine; For I by vow am so embodied yours That she which marries you must marry me, Either both or none.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Your reputation comes too short for my daughter; you are no husband for her.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: My lord, this is a fond and desperate creature Whom sometime I have laugh'd with. Let your highness Lay a more noble thought upon mine honour Than for to think that I would sink it here.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Sir, for my thoughts, you have them ill to friend Till your deeds gain them; fairer prove your honour Than in my thought it lies!

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Good my lord, Ask him upon his oath, if he does think He had not my virginity.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What say'st thou to her?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: She's impudent, my lord, And was a common gamester to the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: He does me wrong, my lord; if I were so He might have bought me at a common price. Do not believe him. O, behold this ring, Whose high respect and rich validity Did lack a parallel; yet for all that He gave it to a commoner o' the camp, If I be one.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: He blushes, and 'tis it. Of six preceding ancestors, that gem Conferr'd by testament to th' sequent issue, Hath it been owed and worn. This is his wife; That ring's a thousand proofs.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Methought you said You saw one here in court could witness it.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: I did, my lord, but loath am to produce So bad an instrument; his name's Parolles.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: I saw the man today, if man he be.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Find him, and bring him hither.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: What of him? He's quoted for a most perfidious slave, With all the spots o' the world tax'd and debauch'd: Whose nature sickens but to speak a truth. Am I or that or this for what he'll utter, That will speak anything?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: She hath that ring of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I think she has. Certain it is I lik'd her And boarded her i' the wanton way of youth. She knew her distance, and did angle for me, Madding my eagerness with her restraint, As all impediments in fancy's course Are motives of more fancy; and in fine, Her infinite cunning with her modern grace, Subdu'd me to her rate; she got the ring, And I had that which any inferior might At market-price have bought.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: I must be patient. You that have turn'd off a first so noble wife May justly diet me. I pray you yet,- Since you lack virtue, I will lose a husband- Send for your ring, I will return it home, And give me mine again.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: I have it not.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What ring was yours, I pray you?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Sir, much like The same upon your finger.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Know you this ring? This ring was his of late.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: And this was it I gave him, being abed.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: The story then goes false you threw it him Out of a casement.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: I have spoke the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: My lord, I do confess the ring was hers.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: You boggle shrewdly; every feather starts you. Is this the man you speak of?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Ay, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Tell me, sirrah, but tell me true I charge you, Not fearing the displeasure of your master, Which on your just proceeding, I'll keep off,- By him and by this woman here what know you?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: So please your majesty, my master hath been an honourable gentleman. Tricks he hath had in him, which gentlemen have.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Come, come, to the purpose. Did he love this woman?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Faith, sir, he did love her; but how?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: How, I pray you?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: He did love her, sir, as a gentleman loves a woman.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: How is that?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: He lov'd her, sir, and lov'd her not.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: As thou art a knave and no knave. What an equivocal companion is this!

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: I am a poor man, and at your majesty's command.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: He's a good drum, my lord, but a naughty orator.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Do you know he promised me marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Faith, I know more than I'll speak.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: But wilt thou not speak all thou know'st?

dialogues.speaker: Parolles
dialogues.line: Yes, so please your majesty. I did go between them as I said; but more than that, he loved her, for indeed he was mad for her, and talked of Satan, and of Limbo, and of furies, and I know not what: yet I was in that credit with them at that time that I knew of their going to bed; and of other motions, as promising her marriage, and things which would derive me ill will to speak of; therefore I will not speak what I know.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Thou hast spoken all already, unless thou canst say they are married; but thou art too fine in thy evidence; therefore stand aside. This ring, you say, was yours?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Ay, my good lord.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Where did you buy it? Or who gave it you?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: It was not given me, nor I did not buy it.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Who lent it you?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: It was not lent me neither.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Where did you find it then?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: I found it not.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: If it were yours by none of all these ways, How could you give it him?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: I never gave it him.

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: This woman's an easy glove, my lord; she goes off and on at pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: This ring was mine, I gave it his first wife.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: It might be yours or hers for ought I know.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Take her away, I do not like her now. To prison with her. And away with him. Unless thou tell'st me where thou hadst this ring, Thou diest within this hour.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: I'll never tell you.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Take her away.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: I'll put in bail, my liege.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I think thee now some common customer.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: By Jove, if ever I knew man, 'twas you.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Wherefore hast thou accus'd him all this while?

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Because he's guilty, and he is not guilty. He knows I am no maid, and he'll swear to't: I'll swear I am a maid, and he knows not. Great King, I am no strumpet, by my life; I am either maid, or else this old man's wife.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: She does abuse our ears; to prison with her.

dialogues.speaker: Diana
dialogues.line: Good mother, fetch my bail. Stay, royal sir; The jeweller that owes the ring is sent for, And he shall surety me. But for this lord Who hath abus'd me as he knows himself, Though yet he never harm'd me, here I quit him. He knows himself my bed he hath defil'd; And at that time he got his wife with child. Dead though she be, she feels her young one kick; So there's my riddle: one that's dead is quick, And now behold the meaning.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Is there no exorcist Beguiles the truer office of mine eyes? Is't real that I see?

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: No, my good lord; 'Tis but the shadow of a wife you see, The name, and not the thing.

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: Both, both. O, pardon!

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: O, my good lord, when I was like this maid; I found you wondrous kind. There is your ring, And, look you, here's your letter. This it says, ‘When from my finger you can get this ring, And is by me with child, &c.' This is done; Will you be mine now you are doubly won?

dialogues.speaker: Bertram
dialogues.line: If she, my liege, can make me know this clearly, I'll love her dearly, ever, ever dearly.

dialogues.speaker: Helena
dialogues.line: If it appear not plain, and prove untrue, Deadly divorce step between me and you! O my dear mother, do I see you living?

dialogues.speaker: Lafew
dialogues.line: Mine eyes smell onions; I shall weep anon.  Good Tom Drum, lend me a handkercher. So, I thank thee. Wait on me home, I'll make sport with thee. Let thy courtesies alone, they are scurvy ones.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Let us from point to point this story know, To make the even truth in pleasure flow.  If thou beest yet a fresh uncropped flower, Choose thou thy husband, and I'll pay thy dower; For I can guess that by thy honest aid, Thou kept'st a wife herself, thyself a maid. Of that and all the progress more and less, Resolvedly more leisure shall express. All yet seems well, and if it end so meet, The bitter past, more welcome is the sweet. _The king's a beggar, now the play is done; All is well ended if this suit be won, That you express content; which we will pay With strife to please you, day exceeding day. Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts; Your gentle hands lend us, and take our hearts._
